2026 Outlook: AI Apps and Agents Take Center Stage. Our 110-page 2026 Internet Outlook report lays the foundation for our expectations for the Internet in 2026. We lay out 10 key predictions and a bonus prediction across the space, many of which focus on continued investment in and the proliferation of AI, as we expect agents and AI applications to scale meaningfully in 2026E. BMO 2026 Internet Outlook Top Picks: GOOGL , AMZN , TTWO and DKNG.

1) Agent Race Will Narrow in 2026E with the Deployment and Validation of Agents. We believe that success will be measured by which companies can most effectively translate their models into verifiable real-world value for enterprises and consumers. 2) The AI Application Layer Begins to Scale Meaningfully , leading to increased adoption of AI tools by consumers and enterprises. The Big Question: How will agentic AI applications impact various subsectors? 3) The CapEx Super-Cycle Will Continue in 2026E with Signs of Further Growth into 2027E as leading cloud providers like AMZN and GOOGL (and non-cloud META) continue to ramp CapEx spend to go after the AI opportunity.

4) Advancements in AI Move it from the Digital to the Physical with Robotics. Companies' integration of robotics has been underway for decades, and AI is expanding the physical productivity frontier by providing the intelligence that powers robotics. We anticipate AI operating as the brain will drive a step-function increase in robotic and physical AI capabilities (such as smart glasses) in 2026E and beyond. 5) AV Industry Transitions from Proof-of-Concept to Business Model Validation, with success hinging on achieving operational efficiency, sustainable unit economics, and high utilization rates, while maintaining safety standards. 6) AMZN Makes a Meaningful Acquisition Around its AI Ambitions , making a $1B+ acquisition in the space. AMZN has only made six $1B+ acquisitions in its history, and we believe a sizable AI acquisition would help close the perceived gap in its AI capabilities.

7) Content Creators Continue to Create, Driving Engagement and Advertising Revenue as both YouTube and Meta launched tools for Creators to better monetize their content in late 2025, which sets up for a strong 2026E. 8) Age Verification Proliferates Across The Internet, Impacting Social, Gaming, and AI Businesses, presenting a headwind to growth. While age verification will support online safety, it is likely to affect time spent online and monetization. 9) UGC Game Development Levels Up as Competitors Ramp Investments in an Attempt to Catch Up to RBLX . Expect TTWO to dive into the UGC opportunity ahead of the release of GTA VI . 10) Travel Growth Resets Higher as Gen Z Leans into Experiences and Agents Begin to Take Over . We believe that online travel will remain one of the biggest beneficiaries of new AI capabilities as agentic AI becomes the latest OS in travel. BONUS: Affordability Remains in Focus for Retail as the macro picture softens and a K-shaped consumption pattern settles in.

· Cracks in the low-income consumer · Supply chain disruptions around the AI infrastructure build-out (energy?) · Failure of businesses in scaling AI applications to enterprises/consumers · Tariffs and inflationary pressures · Geopolitical pressures, specifically between the U.S. and China Our Top Picks for 2026E: GOOGL, AMZN, TTWO and DKNG

It has been three years since the release of ChatGPT in November 2022, marking the era of AI that continues to dominate the tech landscape. While the AI leaders continue to push progress forward, the current implementation of AI remains uneven. According to a McKinsey survey , 9 out of 10 organizations are regularly using AI but are still in a pilot phase. Ultimately, the current gap between extensive piloting and full deployment signals a significant untapped opportunity for businesses to deepen AI integration and engagement. However, on the consumer side, more than half of American adults (61%) have used AI in the past six months, and nearly one in five rely on it every day ( Menlo Ventures ), with plenty of opportunity to capitalize on growing familiarity.

The rapid advancement and adoption of LLMs have now laid the necessary foundation for agentic AI, with the competitive race kicking off with Anthropic's Computer Use preview in October 2024 . Despite Anthropic being first out of the gate, the field remains wide open as agents from various providers continue to penetrate both consumer and enterprise markets. AI Agents are quickly becoming the 'next big thing.' By 2028E, Gartner predicts that 33% of enterprise software applications will include agentic AI, up from less than 1% in 2024, with at least 15% of day-today work decisions being made autonomously through AI agents. As agent competition narrows, we believe that 2026E will become a crucial year for deployment and validation, in which agent success will be measured by which companies can most effectively translate their models into verifiable, real-world value. The Al Agent Wave

Source: Gartner artificial intelligence; PortCo portfolio com 'pany; TPU = tensor processing unit; WAN = wide-area network 833347 Gartner

Before we get into agents, it is essential to differentiate between agentic AI and AI agents (or agents), which both get used interchangeably but are not the same. Essentially, agentic AI is a system across multiple domains, while an AI agent works independently. · Agentic AI : A system that orchestrates multiple AI agents that are goal-driven and deliver on tasks independently with limited supervision. The system can manage numerous agents and agent workflows (IBM). · Agents: A specific component within agentic systems that is designed to handle tasks and processes with a degree of autonomy. Often powered by Large Language Models (LLMs) or Specialized Language Models (SLMs) for specific tasks. The agent operates alone on a task and treats each task in isolation (IBM). Exhibit 1 - Gartner's Emerging AI Agent Landscape Source: Gartner

The agent race is complex, and winning will require creating ecosystems, platforms, infrastructure, and solutions that span the AI value chain. The stakes in agents are significant, with a predicted total spending of $512 billion between 2025E and 2029E, with cumulative AI-related technology spend expected to be $3.3 trillion (Exhibit 5). We continue to believe the AI evolution, particularly with the rise of agentic AI, is unprecedented, given that consumers and enterprises can take advantage of it through the internet, which is accessible to 5.5B people via mobile devices, thereby enabling global mass adoption and usage of agentic technology. Agentic Opportunity is Still Early... For Enterprises and Consumers. Though generative AI (Gen AI) has captured headlines with its meteoric rise to popularity, AI agents are quickly becoming the 'next big thing.' By 2028, Gartner predicts that 33% of enterprise software applications will include agentic AI, up from less than 1% in 2024, with at least 15% of day-to-day work decisions being made autonomously through AI agents.

According to McKinsey, 23% of respondents report that their organizations are scaling an agentic AI system within their enterprises (that is, expanding the deployment and adoption of the technology across at least one business function), and an additional 39% say they have begun experimenting with AI agents. Most companies reported scaling agents in one or two functions. In any given business function, no more than 10% of respondents say their organizations are scaling AI agents (Exhibit 3), indicating that the agentic opportunity remains early, with substantial runwayahead, as every business function expects to experiment with agents next year. However, deployment may take time as enterprises prepare their technology stack and infrastructure. Deployment will likely experience many hurdles, but companies focusing on agentic AI efforts to develop workflows are more likely to deliver a positive outcome, given the amount of support needed.

Consumers Agents Likely to be Driven by Scale. In consumer, we anticipate adoption will be faster than enterprises given LLM's agents partnerships across shopping, travel, and events, and WAU for ChatGPT of 900M and Gemini App MAUs of 650M. The initial adoption ramp will likely resemble the adoption of LLMs, with large step-ups in users following technology upgrades and releases (Exhibit 4).

Phase of AI agent use at respondents' organizations, by business function (%) Agent Deployment Planning to Use Within Year Source: BMO Capital Markets, McKinsey No Agents Deployed

Phase of AI agent use at respondents' organizations, by business function (%) Planning to Use Within Year Experimenting Piloting Scaling Fully Scaled Source: BMO Capital Markets, McKinsey Exhibit 4 - Recent AI Advances has Led to Major Step Up in Users for OpenAI and Google (in M) Exhibit 5 - Agentic Spend Relative to Cumulative AI Spend (2029E) OpenAI's ChatGPT Weekly Active Users (WAU) and Google's Gemini App (MAU) Source: BMO Capital Markets Source: BMO Capital Markets, Gartner

We remain bullish on Agents given their ability to integrate across multiple platforms and penetrate almost every industry. We currently view Google, Amazon, Anthropic, and OpenAI as the most likely leaders in agents, given their offerings for both consumers and enterprises, as well as in platform frameworks and APIs. Among the current agent frontrunners, GOOGL and AMZN stand out given their full-stack offerings and consumer and enterprise agent products. Recently, Anthropic outperformed rivals on almost every agent benchmark with its latest model release (Exhibit 6, 7, 8). OpenAI continues to post strong model scores but holds a unique advantage through its consumer adoption of ChatGPT, which offers a powerful scaling mechanism. What remains to be seen is how LLMs will continue to capture value and support revenue growth, given that AI is capital-intensive. Notably, OpenAI, which has invested billions to improve ChatGPT, has only 5% of its 900M WAU users paying for the service.

As AI continues to become more of a commodity, we believe that the only options are to win the agent race by 1) controlling the entire AI stack from custom silicon to foundational models to hardware devices, and/or 2) mass scale through consumer products .

Based on the above, we believe Google is in the best position given its: 1. Full-stack approach with TPUs, LLM, and Android devices, and 2. Leadership position in consumer search. We believe its existing relationship and touchpoints with enterprises and consumers position it better than rivals to integrate agents directly into its apps/infrastructure, allowing consumers to benefit from agents in the applications they already use. Google's Agentic Consumer Offering to Scale from Search and the Broader Google Ecosystem. In 2025, Google released and integrated various agentic features into Chrome, Gemini, and AI Mode, and, given the massive reach of Chrome's 73.2% market share , Gemini's 650 million MAUs, and 2 billion monthly AI Mode users, we expect agentic adoption to ramp significantly in 2026E.

Similar to OpenAI and Anthropic, access to Gemini's agentic capabilities in AI Mode and the Gemini app requires a subscription. However, unlike the two LLM providers, Google is best positioned to monetize its AI and agents, given its current advertising infrastructure and its ability to incorporate sponsored listings across its ecosystem. Agent Products:

· Web Browsing: Gemini can work across multiple tabs and browse live web pages in the background to gather information across multiple sites, compare options, and even help users complete bookings. · Applications in Travel and Shopping: ○ Google users in the US will now have access to several new AI shopping features through AI Mode and the Gemini App. The new features include targeting tasks such as searching for products, comparing similar items, tracking prices, and agent checkout. Users can click into items, visit retailer sites, see historic pricing data, and track price changes, all from AI Mode. AI Mode will track prices over time and notify users via text or email when a product price drops. ○ Google announced it is rolling out agentic booking for restaurants on AI Mode in the U.S. (no Labs opt-in required), with plans to add agentic booking for flights and hotels directly in AI Mode.

· Assistant Across the Google Ecosystem: Gemini Agent can leverage connected apps across the Google ecosystem, such as Gmail, Google Calendar, Google Drive, Keep, Tasks, Google Maps, and YouTube. For example, Gemini can manage users' inboxes by asking Gemini to create tasks, archive emails, and even draft a response for you to review, edit, and send. · Agents on Android?: Google has been fortifying its Android devices with Gemini, turning them into an AI advisor. We wouldn't be surprised to see Android become deeply embedded with agentic capabilities in the future. · Gemini Coming to Google Home : The smart home ecosystem (Nest, Doorbell Home Speaker) is powered by Gemini, making it a more intelligent AI assistant. Similar to Android, we anticipate the company will integrate agentic capabilities at some point. We believe the opportunity for consumer home agents is significant, and believe GOOGL is well-positioned to gain market share over time, given the massive amount of data from Android devices and Smart Homes.

Exhibit 9 - Example of an Agent Working Across the Google Ecosystem Source: BMO Capital Markets

its agentic and AI offering. Particularly attractive are its Tensor Processing Units (TPUs), which we consistently hear from technology industry insiders are the best alternative to NVDA's CUDA-based GPUs. Notably, more than 70% of GCP customers use Google's AI, and 13 million developers have built with its Gemini models. This provides Google an advantage over OpenAI and Anthropic, which can only offer models. Back in October, the company launched Gemini Enterprise, an advanced agentic platform that provides companies with toolkits to build AI assistants and agents. AI agents can access, combine, and analyze information from internal systems and Google AI tools like Code Assist and Deep Research within a single enterprise workflow. In terms of pricing, Gemini Enterprise standard and 'plus' editions start at $30 per seat per month. A cheaper Gemini Business annual plan, intended for small businesses, startups, or individual departments within a larger company, costs $21 per seat per month.

Since its launch, the company has gained 2 million subscribers across 700 companies, assuming a 50/50 split would add $600 million in annual revenue. Exhibit 10 - Examples of Select Google Agentic Platforms, Programs, and Tools

Amazon's position in the agent race remains competitive given its potential for an agentic consumer offering on Amazon.com, and an enterprise offering with Bedrock and AgentCore. AWS continues to offer the best-in-class full-stack Cloud solution for both start-ups and large enterprises. Ramping up integrations of AI agents for both consumer and business use cases is a near-term tailwind for usage, especially with recent agent/agentic announcements at AWS Re:Invent ( see our note here ). Furthermore, AI agents are revolutionizing customer experiences, presenting a new growth opportunity due to incremental inference workloads. Amazon's AI shopper assistant Rufus is already making a significant impact. While Rufus is an assistant rather than an agent, the tool's performance has been impressive, as CEO Andrew Jassy noted on the company's 3Q25 call: '[Rufus] is on track to deliver over $10 billion in incremental annualized sales'.

Rufus gained 250 million active customers in 2025, and those who used the chatbot were 60% more likely to complete a purchase. Given Amazon's backing and partnership with Anthropic, we would not be surprised if Rufus receives agentic features supported by Claude. Notably, during Black Friday, Amazon reported a 75% daily increase in Rufus-assisted sessions that resulted in purchases, compared to just 35% for non-Rufus sessions. The gap between AI-assisted and non-assisted confirms a broader trend that consumers are increasingly using AI to guide shopping decisions. We believe that some agentic adoption by users is highly likely, given Amazon's scale and reach as the number one e-commerce website in the U.S., its positioning as the eighth most-visited website globally, and, over the last 2 years, its ability to drive an average of 2.71M monthly users (SimilarWeb).

'...Less than 20% of workloads at this point have moved to the cloud...I think it's [Agentic is] an enormous potential for many of our customers and if you think about all of the value that we've already seen from generative AI today, from generating of content to summarizations to things like that, I think that led to 10%, 20%, 30% efficiency gains and benefits for customers. I think the promise of agentic is when these models can go and actually accomplish tasks for you and long-running tasks where they can go do stuff, where they can use tools, they can use browsers, they can use capabilities out there, they can use text editors, et cetera. That's when you start to see not 20% gains but 200% gains."

Source: Amazon Alexa+ with Anthropic Lays the Foundation for AI Personal Assistants and Agents. Alexa+ intelligence is powered by both Amazon's Nova Models and Anthropic's Claude, significantly improving its capabilities over the previous version. Like Google Home, Alexa+ has been a massive boon for users, with agentic-like properties that can use natural-language requests to do nearly anything around the house. We believe the opportunity for consumer AI is significant, and believe AMZN is well-positioned to have a share of the market over time with Alexa+ and Rufus, the AI personal shopper. However, we believe AMZN's opportunity in enterprise AI is likely stronger, given their strengths in AWS and Amazon Bedrock.

Bedrock's AgentCore Wide Offering of LLMs Remains Attractive. Amazon Bedrock AgentCore is an agentic platform for building, deploying, and operating highly effective agents securely at scale using any framework and houses 17 of the leading LLMs on the platform, as well as its own Nova Series. We view the platforms' agnostic offering as vital, and we firmly believe there will be multiple winners in the foundational model space in the long term. Bedrock is cementing itself as the agnostic AI platform for enterprises to build AI applications on. Amazon's AWS: All in on Agents at re:Invent 2025. At this year's re:Invent 2025 ( See more details and breakdown of products in our note here ), AWS announced several new agents that will help redefine the software development and utilization process. These agents (discussed in exhibit 12) can work for hours (and even days) on specific tasks without human intervention, ultimately producing a tangible output that meets the initial request.

Amazon has positioned AgentCore as a one-stop shop for agent building, given the wide variety and capabilities of its offering. While we are unable to confirm the effectiveness of these agents, we believe this is the future of software development, deployment, and monitoring. Additional Agent Products Announced at re:Invent 2025 · Frontier Agents: A new class of agents driving a step-function change in capabilities. These agents are autonomous and massively scalable; once given a goal, they will go out and achieve the desired output without human intervention. The agents are also long-running and may work for days to achieve their goals without human intervention. These agents will run alongside your workflow to automate development tasks. A user assigns a task, and the Kiro Autonomous Agent will work to complete it. All of this work will take place in the background, allowing the 2025

engineering team to remain focused on the bigger picture. We believe the roll-out of these agents (and competing agents from other platforms) will drive a step-function change in software development. · AWS Security Agent: Allows users to build secure apps from design to deployment. It embeds security upstream and proactively secures applications throughout the development lifecycle. The agent will also scan code for potential vulnerabilities, helping you to ensure your code is secure before entering and while in production.

OpenAI's biggest advantage in the agentic race is its 900 million WAU on ChatGPT which the company has integrated with agentic features. However, as noted previously, only 5% of those users pay for a subscription tier that gives access to the agentic features. OpenAI is heavily focused on expanding its enterprise offering with its API access and premium subscriptions for ChatGPT Enterprise which has over a million organizations subscribed and 7 million workplace seats. Over the last year the company has aggressively expanded its enterprise agents offering, with Agentic Commerce Protocol (co-developed with Stripe) and the Agent Kit to help developers build and deploy agents, directly competing with the major hyperscalers.

Unlike the hyperscalers, OpenAI lacks cloud infrastructure and hardware but has announced many deals and partnerships to own the full AI stack including: moving into hardware with the acquisition of io (acquired for $6.5 billion), building out data centers with Oracle and Softbank, and working with Broadcom to design its own chips. We view the deals as OpenAI trying to own a full-stack ecosystem to rival hyperscalers and control the entire lifecycle of its models and agents. However, many of the recent deals OpenAI has struck to build out its technology platform with chipmakers, cloud computing companies, and others are worryingly circular. Fueling market concerns that the company's technological progress may stall. Exhibit 13 - OpenAI Total Revenue Projections ($ in B) with BMO Estimates by Segment Exhibit 14 - OpenAI Projected Agent Revenue ($ in B) and YoY Growth (%) Source: BMO Capital Markets, The Information Source: BMO Capital Markets, The Information

Integration of Agent Capabilities into ChatGPT. As mentioned above, OpenAI's most significant advantage is its impressive consumer reach with its 900M WAUs of ChatGPT; however, only 5% pay. With its latest models, OpenAI is incorporating agentic features into ChatGPT and has launched Atlas, a web browser with agentic capabilities from Agent Mode for Plus, Pro, and business subscribers. The launch marks a step toward a future where the web could become increasingly through agentic systems. We will continue to watch whether the company's incorporated agentic features will ultimately drive the conversion of free users to paying users. Agent Products:

· Agent Mode through ChatGPT: More advanced than Operator (see below) as it is the primary user interface that leverages agentic models like GPT-5/GPT-5.1. Users can interact with it via text or voice to perform tasks, generate content, and access specialized tools such as web search and code interpretation. · Operator: A research preview agent capable of automating tasks online by using its own browser to navigate and interact with websites (typing, clicking, scrolling). Less advanced and less capable than Agent Mode. · Deep Research: An AI agent that performs extensive web browsing, data analysis, and synthesis to deliver comprehensive reports. · Atlas: Web browser (available only on Mac iOS) where users can turn on 'agent mode' that can fill up online shopping baskets, plan trips, and book appointments. It can also search across multiple tabs in the background.

· Hardware: OpenAI acquired former Apple designer Johnny Ives's io for $6.5 billion with plans to build an AI device. The device will likely serve as a gateway for users to interact with AI agents. However, the device has faced technological delays and has been pushed back from a 2026E release to 2027E. Strong Enterprise Offering. OpenAI has primarily targeted gains in consumer share, with the company only launching its enterprise offering in 2023, since expanding to include various agentic tools and protocols. We suspect that, given the lack of paying consumers, the majority of the company's revenue is generated from businesses. The company's enterprise offering has over 1 million customers and more than 7 million total ChatGPT for Work seats. As the company lacks the infrastructure to support its services, we continue to believe that leading hyperscalers like Amazon and Google are well-positioned to benefit from OpenAI's buildout, as we expect this will create a new digital economy that runs on top of AWS/GCP and other cloud services. Agent Products:

· Agentic Commerce Protocol: An open standard for AI commerce that lets AI agents and businesses complete purchases. The protocol was co-developed with Stripe and other merchants to enable secure, easy adoption. · Agent Kit: The new toolkit will help developers build and deploy AI agents faster and better optimize agent workflows. The product will directly compete with Microsoft, Amazon, Anthropic, and Google's offering of agentic tools, as the company looks to bring more developers inside the OpenAI ecosystem. We note that Amazon and Google both announced new competing AI enterprise offerings this week (see below for more). · Codex: A cloud-based software engineering agent that can work on many tasks in parallel, powered by Codex-1. Codex can perform agentic tasks such as writing features, answering questions about a user's codebase, fixing bugs, and proposing pull requests for review.

The company was first out of the gate, releasing an agent in October 2024 with its preview of Computer Use. Despite being first out of the gate, the company has been slower to launch its GTM products than the competition. However, this is likely due to the company's emphasis on safety and product quality, which has resulted in 1) delivering models on time, and 2) producing some of the best models to date . Despite having less capital and resources than OpenAI and Google, Anthropic has not only kept up with various intelligence benchmarks, but its Claude models have also surpassed its competitors on agentic benchmarks (Exhibit 17). Anthropic's business strategy has primarily focused on enterprise customers, whom we view as stickier, less prone to churn, and with deeper spending than consumers. This strategy has played out very well for the company, with the largest share of enterprise usage and coding (Exhibits 18 and 19), resulting in the company raising its optimistic revenue projections (Exhibit 15).

Source: BMO Capital Markets, The Information Exhibit 16 - Anthropic Revenue Estimates ($ in B) and Optimistic Growth YoY (%) Source: BMO Capital Markets, The Information

t2-bench scored with Anthropic's Sonnet 4.5 Source: BMO Capital Markets, Google, Scale.AI Consumer Adoption Slower but Could See Scale from Partnerships. As mentioned above, Anthropic's business strategy remains focused on enterprise rather than consumers. The company has released consumer products but has been slower to do so, given its strategy, and has limited roll-outs, given its emphasis on product safety and quality. This has meant the company has given up share in the consumer market to its competitors; however, given the company continues to deliver on models often better than the competition, we think over time it is likely to recover some lost ground. Unlike OpenAI and Google, Anthropic does not disclose any metrics on its Claude consumer product. Its consumer subscription pricing is noticeably lower than Google's and OpenAI's, which could help it gain share (Exhibit 20).

· Claude AI in Chrome: The browser-based AI agent launched in September and is now available to all subscribers of its Max plan. The Chrome extension allows users to chat with Claude in a sidebar window and permits Claude to take actions in the browser for select tasks. The extension also integrates with Gmail and Google Calendar, as Gemini does. · Updates to Opus 4.5: The newly released model is better at performing complex multistep tasks on a user's computer and over the internet, which should further support the use of the Claude AI Chrome extension. Anthropic is Strategically Positioned to Dominate the Enterprise AI Sector. We think the company's consistent ability to produce agentic models and tools will continue to drive demand among enterprises. In July, Anthropic surpassed OpenAI in terms of LLM enterprise API market share by usage (Exhibit 18) and has a significant lead in the AI coding market share (Exhibit 19).

Anthropic's strong product offering and model intelligence are driving share gains and have led to a partnership with Microsoft, in which the company announced that Anthropic's LLMs would power more complex tasks in its Copilot suite, supplanting OpenAI, given Anthropic's stronger, more powerful models . While Anthropic doesn't have a full-stack offering or a strong consumer offering, we think its ability to scale across enterprises will continue to generate consistent revenue, especially given its model's leadership in agentic capabilities.

Agent Products: · Claude Developer Platform: The platform allows users to integrate the company's advanced AI models, Opus, Sonnet, and Haiku, into applications via an API, supporting code generation with Claude Code, AI agents, and customer support chatbots, with options for self-serve deployment or custom enterprise solutions. Recent updates include new tools for longer-running agents, an effort parameter for balancing time and capability, and improved context management for multiagent systems. · Claude Code: Agentic coding tool that integrates directly into a user's terminal or IDE, allowing it to understand the codebase and perform various tasks using natural language commands. It can build features from descriptions, debug and fix issues, navigate codebases, automate tasks such as listing fixes and release notes, refactor code, and manage Git workflows, including commits and GitHub pushes.

· MCP: An open-sourced standard for connecting AI assistants and agents across content repositories, business tools, and development environments. Ultimately, MCP replaces a fragmented system and prevents data silos, allowing agents to better communicate with one another, improving the quality of AI through data sharing, and simplifying integration. While agent adoption from consumers and enterprises has already begun, a potential slowdown could be caused by any one of the following: · Infrastructure (physical and digital): For agents to scale, it will require immense computational power for training and inference, chips, cloud computing capacity, electrical power and cooling, and network connectivity. Any slowdown forces an immediate slowdown or retraction of agent use. · Technology: If technological innovations do not continue to advance and agent growth flatlines, particularly among consumers given limited use, it could retract. · Consumers getting comfortable with the product: Future adoption hinges on whether endusers, both consumers and enterprises, find the agents trustworthy, helpful, and easy to use. · Security Risks: Agents process sensitive data; any data leaks or agents acting outside of controls could trigger a complete shutdown of agent activity.

development. We believe 2026 will mark the start of a meaningful ramp in AI applications as developers look to build on leading AI models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and other providers. We believe investors will look back on the evolution of the AI wave and define 2023-2025 as the modeldevelopment era, and view 2026 as the start of the shift into the application layer. Model Development is Not Going Away. To clarify our views, we anticipate that leading model providers will continue to meaningfully invest in model development, which remains a source of significant innovation, as they look to build more intelligent, more capable models that will further enhance the application build-out. We highlight that Google recently topped the charts with the launch of Gemini 3 , which we discussed in depth in our note here, underscoring that innovations in the model layer continue to occur. However, as these models have become increasingly more capable over the last couple of years, we believe the ability for companies to build applications on top of leading foundation models at scale has arrived.

Importantly, we highlight that GOOGL's existing application layer, including Google Maps, Gmail, Google Search, YouTube, and other applications, provides Google with scalable platforms for integrating AI directly. As a result, we believe Google has a massive competitive advantage in scaling its AI applications, given its ability to acquire customers for its AI products at a meaningfully lower customer acquisition cost (CAC) by plugging AI directly into existing products. Furthermore, while they have an existing scale advantage, they also offer best-in-class AI technology, which makes their AI integrations even more valuable. Exhibit 23 - Understanding the AI Tech Stack Source: LeewayHertz Cloud Providers are Clear Beneficiaries of a Scaled Application Layer. Importantly, we believe the hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, and GCP) are well-positioned to be winners as the AI application layer unfolds. Importantly, as AI applications scale, the use of these applications will require inference to be generated in datacenters, ultimately leading to increased spending by these application companies on cloud services that support inference.

This is very similar to the application layer that emerged with the creation of the internet, in which applications like DDOG, SNOW, and TEAM that run on top of the cloud pay cloud companies to host their applications in the cloud (which largely shows up in their respective COGS). As a result, the cloud market is a clear beneficiary as AI apps scale. Additionally, we believe cloud vendors like AWS, GCP, and Azure may even compete directly with their own applications, as they do in the cloud, where they offer applications that sometimes compete with companies that run on top of them. We believe these cloud companies will identify specific AI applications to scale, allowing them to benefit directly from the rise of their own AI applications. However, we note that the success of their own applications can be somewhat cannibalistic, as they will then compete with the same customers who offer competing apps.

Nonetheless, we see the hyperscalers as one of the best ways to play the AI application opportunity, allowing investors to avoid betting on riskier AI application startups that could fail to scale an AI application with lasting impact over the long term.

CapEx Super-Cycle to Continue: Leading cloud companies (and META) are set to increase CapEx again in 2026E as they build out the critical infrastructure needed to pursue the AI opportunity. We expect AMZN to continue to lead the way, with $163B in 2026E CapEx, followed by GOOGL at $138B, MSFT at $106B, and META at $104B. Additionally, we believe CapEx spend is set to grow again in 2027E as big tech continues to invest in infrastructure to support the long-term opportunity. We highlight that recent commentary from management suggests there is no slowdown in sight on CapEx spending (more on this later in our outlook). Exhibit 24 - Annual Calendar Year Capex Spend (in $B) Estimates are BMOe, except MSFT which is consensus Source: Company data, Visible Alpha, BMO Capital Markets

CapEx Growth to Decelerate YoY in 2026E, But CapEx Growth to Remain Robust. We expect cumulative CapEx spend by AMZN, GOOGL, MSFT, and META to accelerate to 59% growth (vs. 56% in 2024) and reach $366B for 2025E. In 2026, we expect CapEx across mega-cap tech to grow 40% YoY, reaching $510B. We expect this growth to meaningfully decelerate to 11% in 2027E, as the mega-cap tech investment cycle peaks. Our Cloud Experts Expect Ramping CapEx In 2026E: We highlight our recent pre-3Q25 earnings cloud checks with a cloud expert who has $4.7B into annual cloud spend, said they anticipate hyperscaler CapEx to continue to ramp through at least mid-2026 , given that new NVDA Rubin next-gen GPUs could support a longer ramp during the CapEx super-cycle.

Exhibit 25 - Cummulative CapEx of AMZN, GOOGL, MSFT and META with YoY Growth chart shows the combined CY CapEx for AMZN, GOOGL, MSFT and META Source: Company data, Visible Alpha, BMO Capital Markets Despite Massive CapEx Ramp, Mega-Cap Tech Will Continue to Be FCF Positive: Given the $500B that mega-cap tech players AMZN, GOOGL, MSFT, and META will be spending in 2026E, we believe it is important to note that these companies will continue to generate positive FCF even as they meaningfully ramp investments behind the AI opportunity. For perspective, after subtracting spend for capital expenditure in 2025E, consensus estimates suggest AMZN, GOOGL, and META will each generate $13B, $65B, and $45B in Free Cash Flow, respectively.

In 2026E, consensus implies that META's FCF falls to $23B, as both AMZN and GOOGL increase to $39B/ $70B, respectively, underscoring the ability for mega-cap tech vendors to leverage the cash they generate from their existing operations to fund their investment initiatives rather than needing to raise capital to invest in the business. With that said, we note that these leading hyperscalers have all recently raised several billion dollars each in new debt. Exhibit 26 - Mega-Cap 2025E Free Cash Flow Estimates Data is Consensus Source: BMO Capital Markets, Visible Alpha

Data is Consensus Source: BMO Capital Markets, Visible Alpha Exhibit 28 - Mega-Cap Cash, Debt and Net Debt Profiles as of 3Q25 Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports

Intention of Slowing Down: Despite meaningful push-back from investors around the current CapEx super-cycle and the potential ROI from the spend, we don't believe these spenders (AMZN, GOOGL, META, and MSFT) have any intention of slowing down their spend. Importantly, we believe these companies believe they are in the middle of the largest investment cycle of our lifetimes, with a transformative outcome they think will rival the creation of the Internet and the economic opportunity that resulted. Because of this, we believe these companies will continue to spend as much as they can, especially given that every dollar they do not spend will be spent by their competitors, which would ultimately leave them even further behind in the race. Ultimately, we would not be surprised if these companies end up over-building their infrastructure buildouts when we look back; however, we believe the risk of overbuilding is not nearly as significant as the risk of underbuilding, as companies will eventually be able to grow into the capacity over time.

For perspective, many tech industry leaders are discussing building data centers in space , underscoring the expected scale of this infrastructure build-out to support future AI workloads. This is very reminiscent of the COVID-driven fulfillment build-out that AMZN undertook to grow its eCommerce fulfillment capabilities to support the ramping eCommerce demand during the pandemic. While AMZN ended up building more capacity than they needed at the time, these investments helped secure AMZN's moat in eCommerce, with excess fulfillment capacity that they eventually grew into over the ensuing years. Return on Said CapEx Spending Remains The Largest Debate: While we find it difficult to debate whether the CapEx Supercycle will continue into 2026E (given recent management commentary), we believe the most significant debate centers on the actual return on CapEx spending.

While we believe it is hard to define the actual ROI, we think that hyperscalers like AWS, Azure, and GCP have clear monetization opportunities on their spend, as CapEx spend behind cloud infrastructure is essentially immediately rented out as part of the cloud business to companies that need to access compute for AI workloads and model training. While we believe this ROI opportunity is clear, it is less clear for ad platforms like META, which have been seeking AI investments to drive AI-related improvements in ad spend on their platforms. Ultimately, we suspect the debate around the true ROI on the current CapEx cycle will continue. Still, we don't believe we will have an accurate estimate until the application layer of the AI build-out begins to scale meaningfully, which we think will support material value creation across the entire AI stack.

While companies' integration of robotics has been underway for decades, AI is expanding the physical productivity frontier by providing the intelligence that powers robotics and smart consumer technology, including smart glasses. Often referred to as "physical AI", the AI enables the hardware to autonomously perceive, reason, and adapt to unstructured, dynamic real-world environments. We believe that deeper penetration of physical AI will have knock-on effects for consumers and enterprises as advancements in LLMs could help unlock $2.9 trillion of economic value in the United States by 2030E ( McKinsey ). This will be especially true if enterprises can successfully prepare their employees and redesign workflows to accommodate people, agents, smart technologies, and robots working together. McKinsey further estimates that, in theory, robotics technologies could automate activities that account for 57% of US work hours today.

The robotics industry is a rapidly growing investment theme, with experts projecting a compound annual growth rate of 13% to 16%. In 2Q25 alone, robotics investments totaled at least $8.8 billion across 222 global deals, with the United States and China dominating. Recently, reinvestment in robotics has re-emerged with 1) increased acquisitions activity as seen by Amazon and Google, and 2) more cash allocated to CapEx and opex. The opportunity remains early, but given advancements in AI, we anticipate that robot and robotics investments should drive consumer and enterprise breakthroughs in 2026E and beyond. Amazon and Google maintain a significant lead in the robotics sector, given their ability to leverage massive capital, an established presence of robots in the market, and a powerful data flywheel that continuously fuels AI-driven improvements in robotics.

Nevertheless, OpenAI and Anthropic are rapidly entering the field, with OpenAI's aggressive hiring of robotics engineers and Anthropic's Project Fetch . This experiment measured the "AI uplift" provided by the Claude model during the training of a robot dog. In terms of physical AI in consumer devices, Meta, Google, and Amazon are all working on developing smart glasses that are integrated with AI. However, the opportunity remains early, as both hardware and software advancements are needed to achieve mass adoption. Advancements in Robotics could unlock $2.9 trillion of economic value in the United States by 2030E per a McKinsey report. Like many technological waves, adoption depends on implementation, expense, piloting time, and deployment. Case in point, cloud adoption is only 20% (as of 2023) despite the technology being widely available since the mid-2000s.

While we are bullish on the technology into 2026E, there is a higher risk of slower deployment given reliance on AI advancements and potential slowdowns in manufacturing. Exhibit 29 - AI has Fueled Robotics VC Deal Activity and Investment ($ in B) Source: BMO Capital Markets, PitchBook

Amazon plans to use more robots than humans in its warehouse. Notably 75% of Amazon's global deliveries are assisted in some way by robotics. Amazon spends enormous sums on automating human effort to enhance productivity and lower labor costs. We expect AMZN 2026E CapEx of $163B to continue supporting its AI and robotics ambitions. The automation of Amazon's facilities and warehouses is approaching a new milestone: soon, there will be as many robots as humans. Amazon's automation team expects the company to avoid hiring more than 160,000 people in the U.S. by 2027. We estimate that it would save roughly $0.30 per item that Amazon picks, packs, and delivers to customers. Notably, the company has deployed more than 1 million robots across its workplaces (per 3Q25 call), with the number of robots approaching its 1.56 million employees (2024).

In 2024, the company opened a three-million-square-foot warehouse in Louisiana that used automation and artificial intelligence at every step of the fulfillment process. Amazon is using three different automated robotic arms at its new building, including its Sparrow device, which uses suction cups and artificial intelligence software to identify objects by characteristics such as color, shape, and size. Given Amazon's AI capabilities, combined with the use of robotics across the fulfillment network, when a customer clicks the 'buy now' button on Amazon, the fulfillment center's central planning software sends one of 750k mobile robots to fetch inventory and purchased items in real time - we note robotics is a key component of Amazon's retail operations as it allows consumers to receive packages quicker - in 2012 Amazon purchased a robotics company called Kiva for $775 million. "...I think you're going to continue to see us invest very significantly in robotics." - Andy Jassy, Amazon CEO, from 3Q25 Earnings Call Exhibit 30 - Amazon's Robotics Acquisitions

Google has been pursuing its robotics ambitions since 2013; advancements in Gemini have propelled recent robotics research and development efforts. In March, Google DeepMind introduced two AI models, Gemini Robotics and Gemini Robotics-ER. The goal is to make AI useful in the physical world to solve a wide variety of tasks, including ones it has never seen during training. · Gemini Robotics 1.5: Vision-language-action (VLA) model that can use vision, language, and action in the physical world. · Gemini Robotics-ER 1.5: Embodied reasoning model that specializes in understanding physical spaces, planning, and making logical decisions relating to its surroundings. Essentially, enhances Gemini Robotics' understanding of the world, with a particular focus on spatial reasoning. Building humanoid robots that extend their smart home ecosystem. Google has partnered with Apptronik to create the next generation of humanoid robots and has also partnered with over 60 trusted testers to guide the future of Gemini Robotics-ER.

Given Google's multiple smart home devices like Google Home and Nest, the move is a strategic alignment to integrate advanced robotic capabilities with its existing ecosystem, potentially paving the way for humanoid robots to serve as physical assistants within the smart home environment.

Source: Amazon Exhibit 36 - Google's and Approtronik Robot Source: Google Google's SIMA 2 Agents Are a Step Forward in the Future of Agents and Robots. Google's DeepMind launched SIMA 2 (Scalable Instructable Multiworld Agent), an AI that follows basic instructions across a wide range of virtual environments. SIMA is crucial to teaching AI to translate language into action in 3D worlds. The latest version builds on the previous SIMA model, which was an instruction-based agent, but now includes interactive capabilities. This is a significant step in improving agent capabilities. SIMA 2 provides validation for a new path in action-oriented AI, confirming that an AI trained for broad competency can successfully unify the capabilities of many specialized systems into a single, coherent generalist agent. Additionally, DeepMind sees SIMA 2 as a step toward unlocking greater functionality and advances in robots.

The physical AI opportunity in smart glasses remains early, as both hardware and software advancements are needed to achieve mass adoption. We expect adoption of smart glasses to scale from improvements in technical capabilities, as a more robust hardware offering with a built-out developer base is likely to be the core driver of mainstream consumer adoption, along with advances in AI. Despite Meta's current lead in the smart-glass space, we expect its lead to be challenged by multiple deep-pocketed competitors, including GOOGL, AMZN, and APPL, which are developing competing offerings, and SNAP, which has a multi-year head start on its own smart-glasses investments. As well as pressure from Chinese companies like Baidu, which recently launched its own smart glasses powered by Qwen AI . We anticipate a winner-takes-most market, as developers are likely to focus their efforts on the largest platforms with the most significant reach. Ultimately, we think that the smart-glasses market, driven by the potential of Physical AI, is entering a highly competitive phase in 2026.

While the opportunity is still early, we think that the winner will likely be the platform that successfully combines 1) strong hardware, 2) creates a developer ecosystem similar to iPhone and Android, and 3) is powered by a leading AI. Meta Sets The Stage for The Next Major Form Factor. First to market, Meta formally announced the Meta Ray-Ban Display ($799) with an EMG wristband, marking its first smart glasses with a built-in AR display. We expect this step-function product enhancement to help Meta meaningfully expand its glasses sales beyond the roughly two million pairs sold since their October 2023 launch, supported by its affordable price point. We believe the hardware and corresponding subscription/app monetization are still multiple years away from becoming meaningful revenue contributors. Additionally, the company will need to meaningfully improve its AI to compete with Google, Amazon, and Chinese rivals. Google's Two AI Glasses Expected to Launch Next Year, Its Edge Could be Gemini. Google is developing two types of AI-powered glasses, powered by Gemini, and expected to launch next year.

The news comes as Meta is reportedly delaying its glasses launch to improve the product's quality . We think Google could surpass Meta in the smart glasses race, thanks to the performance of its Gemini model and its hardware expertise through Android. · AI-Powered Glasses: Will include built-in speakers, a microphone, and cameras, allowing users to chat with Gemini for assistance. The glasses will consist of an in-lens display that shows information such as directions. · Wired XR Glasses: Supported by Android XR, which are equipped with a 70-degree field of view and optical see-through technology. Similar to mixed reality, the devices layer digital content directly onto a user's view of the physical world. Users will be able to watch YouTube and extend the desktop screen when connected to a computer. The company also announced it is launching Developer Preview 3 of the Android XR SDK, which opens development for AI glasses by providing developers with the tools and APIs. This should help drive user usage and monetization.

Amazon is Using Smart Glasses to Improve Delivery Time. Amazon is taking an enterprise approach, developing smart glasses to help its delivery workers improve the delivery process. The glasses will allow the user to scan and identify packages, follow directions (without needing a phone), and capture proof of delivery. The enabled smart glasses should help shave off delivery time and are currently being trialed by drivers across North America. The company has yet to release any information on the actual efficiencies achieved with the glasses. Amazon offers consumer smart glasses with its Echo Frames; however, adoption is likely limited given the limited feature set. Exhibit 38 - Meta Ray-Ban Displays Source: Meta Exhibit 39 - Demo of Wired XR Glasses Source: Google Exhibit 40 - Amazon's Delivery Glasses Source: Amazon

2025 was a momentous year for autonomous mobility as it marked AV's transition from pilots to scaling commercial operations. In 2025, multiple cities approved driverless robotaxis and/or began testing for future deployment, with many additional cities expected to approve AVs in 2026. In passenger transportation, Waymo surpassed 100 million rider-only miles and over 1 million rides per month in San Francisco and Los Angeles. At the same time, in commercial trucking, Aurora launched driverless commercial freight operations across the Dallas-Houston and Fort Worth-El Paso lanes. As current momentum continues, we expect 2026 to be a critical validation year, with measured but material scale-up for major players - Waymo progressing toward 1 million trips per week (at 450,000 as of Dec 2025), Aurora deploying hundreds of trucks, and Tesla expanding to 8-10 metros. At the same time, we expect regulatory approvals to remain the pacing constraint in AV's expansion.

In 2025, robotaxis achieved meaningful operational scale - Waymo, which we believe is the current market leader, received approval for AV service at three airports and enabled freeway driving for rideronly trips across the Bay Area, Los Angeles, and Phoenix. At the same time, Tesla expanded beyond Austin and the Bay Area, securing ride-hailing approval in Arizona, reporting 250,000 driverless miles in Austin and over 1 million supervised miles in the Bay Area. Zoox launched its Explorers program (for free public rides) in San Francisco and scaled its manufacturing capacity to over 10,000 units per year, with Panasonic cell agreements starting in early 2026. Similarly, autonomous trucking converted to commercial driverless operations in 2025, with Aurora surpassing 100,000 driverless miles across the Dallas-Houston and Fort Worth-El Paso lanes, while targeting hundreds of driverless trucks by the end of 2026.

At the same time, Kodiak AI has achieved over 3 million autonomous miles across more than 10,000 loads and has delivered 8 of the initial 100-truck commercial orders from Atlas Energy Solutions. The company expects to launch long-haul driverless operations in the second half of 2026E. Over the last 12 months, Waymo has pulled ahead as the clear market leader. By the end of 2025, its AV fleet will be operating in 9 markets, up from 3 at the beginning of the year, with expectations to be operational in another eight markets by the end of 2026. Notably, the company is testing in 14 locations, including dense cities like New York and Tokyo, harsh weather conditions like Denver, Colorado, and Michigan, and different driving standards, such as those in London and Tokyo, which drive on the left-hand side.

Chinese government has established a policy to make China the world leader in driverless vehicles by 2035. It has begun aggressively issuing permits for robotaxi testing to stay competitive with the U.S. As a result, we've seen recently a notable expansion of operations by Baidu's Apollo Go, WeRide, and Pony AI. According to a BloombergNEF analysis, Apollo Go , WeRide , and Pony.ai are outnumbering their American competition with more robotaxi projects progressing from testing to various stages of commercialization. However, we note that much of this headway is made in China, where regulations are less strict, and the government heavily subsidizes operators. While the advances made by China's AV companies are impressive, we are cautious about the technology's potential in external markets due to China's less stringent regulations and testing polices.

Baidu Reaches 250K Weekly Robotaxi Rides but Behind Waymo's 450K. Baidu's Apollo Go AV taxi service has surpassed 250,000 weekly rides, but falls short of Waymo's 450K. However, Waymo's latest figure was reported in April and is likely to have increased since then. As we wrote above, the ramp in Baidu's Apollo Go comes as China's government continues to push for AV leadership. The growth in Apollo Go's weekly rides is likely benefiting from looser AV regulations. Baidu's Apollo Go primarily operates robotaxis in Wuhan, Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen, and has announced plans to expand to Hong Kong, Abu Dhabi, and Switzerland. We could see roadblocks in this rollout due to other countries' more stringent regulatory requirements.

Pony AI Operations Break Even in Guangzhou. The company reported that its robotaxi operations in Guangzhou had broken even on a per-car basis, an early indication that AVs are becoming more economically viable. While the number of vehicles in Guangzhou is unknown, the company aims to expand its global fleet to more than 3,000 cars by 2026 and is on track to surpass its 1,000-car target this year, according to recent filings (exhibit 56).

Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports, Bloomberg

2026 should convert 2025's momentum in AV pilots into scaling, revenue-bearing operations. Next year, we expect the autonomous vehicle industry to transition from proof-of-concept to business-model validation. Success likely hinges on achieving operational efficiency, demonstrating sustainable unit economics with high utilization, and maintaining safety standards as the business scales. Key leading indicators to track progress include: 1. Remote-ops ratio improvements, 2. Daily utilization hours approaching 18-20, 3. Vehicle bill-of-materials costs are trending toward the $50,000 profitability threshold, 4. CPUC approval timing, and 5. Airport access permits - all critical for investors assessing the path to commercial viability and operators balancing growth with safety validation requirements. Among the publicly announced 2026 plans, we want to highlight the following. - · Waymo - Maintains a fleet of roughly 2,500 robotaxis (as of Nov 2025) with plans to add at least another 1,000 by 2026. Announced metro launch pipelines include San Diego, Detroit, Las Vegas,

Minneapolis, Tampa, and New Orleans. In Miami and several TX/FL cities, the company has begun a phased rollout of rider access, while in Sacramento, it has expanded its service to driverless non-passenger operations. Lastly, its NYC testing permit was extended through Dec 2025. · Zoox - The company continues its paid service in Las Vegas and its supervised program in San Francisco. Fleet expansion is underpinned by ramping up its Hayward assembly facility and early-2026 Panasonic cell supply. · Tesla - The company's recent Arizona permit complements those in Austin and the Bay Area; further expansion toward its target of 8-10 metros depends on regulatory approvals. Unit economics are expected to continue improving, and several factors will impact their trend, including:

· CapEx - Alphabet signaled a 'significant' CapEx increase in 2026; as Waymo scales infrastructure, rising depreciation and energy costs will pressure the P&L in the near-term, while integrations with Gemini improve the in-car experience. · Partnerships - Lyft invests in depots and an integrated supply system with Waymo to maximize utilization; Avis manages fleet/charging for Waymo in Dallas with vehicles initially on Waymo's balance sheet. The AV regulatory backdrop is expected to improve, too, but most likely at a measured pace. The U.S. remains a patchwork of regulations - Florida and Arizona are relatively supportive; some metros impose monitors; local community pushback can add costs and constrain scaling; NHTSA reviews remain a headline risk. A handful of catalysts for investors to watch include:

1. Waymo's freeway operations performance and new rider-only city launches; 2. Zoox battery-backed fleet growth and addition of paid cities; 3. Tesla rider-only approvals and Cybercab ramp; 4. Expansion of airport access; and 5. Enterprise/transit integrations that drive utilization.

AMZN to Make $1B+ AI Acquisition in 2026: We believe 2026 will be the year AMZN makes a meaningful AI company investment or complete acquisition. We underscore our view by noting that AMZN is expected to spend $163B in CapEx in 2026E, most of which will go towards building out its cloud infrastructure to support the AI opportunity. Given this massive level of CapEx spend (aka investment), we would not be surprised to see AMZN make a $1B+ acquisition in the space that supports the investments it is already making in infrastructure. We believe this type of acquisition could be a tuck-in acquisition that supports the AWS business (possibly around security) or could even be an AI application-driven acquisition, such as an AI coding tool or a foundation model provider (recall AMZN has made significant investments in Anthropic).

AMZN has an AI Perception Issue: Since AI gained traction in 2022, most investors have perceived AWS and Amazon as lagging behind their core large-cap technology peers, including Microsoft and Alphabet. At times, from 2024-1H25, it felt that this perception has even worsened, as investors fear that AWS lacks a leading foundational model and owned-and-operated AI tools. As a result of this perception gap, AMZN's shares have meaningfully underperformed those of its bigtech peers over a multi-year period. While we believe AMZN's 3Q25 results helped reduce some of these fears, the perception remains, and we consider a meaningful acquisition in the space to be one of the quickest and best ways to remove these roadblocks to the story.

AMZN has Made Meaningful Investments in Anthropic: We remind investors that AMZN already has a tight relationship with Anthropic, a leading AI model provider. In November 2024, the two expanded their partnership, with AMZN investing an additional $4B into Anthropic (bringing the total investment to $8B) while Anthropic established AWS as its primary cloud and training partner. We highlight that Anthropic is likely too large at this point for AMZN to acquire fully, and there would likely be regulatory pushback, as well as existing stakeholders (GOOGL, MSFT, NVDA) who might oppose such a transaction. However we wouldn't be surprised if AMZN were to further lean into its ownership stake into Anthropic as they continue to raise capital to build out their Claude model and broader AI application product suite.

AMZN has Only Made a Handful of Sizable Acquisitions in Its History: We highlight that AMZN has only made six acquisitions over $1B and two over $5B, underscoring AMZN's ability to stand up internal businesses rather than relying on inorganic growth/acquisitions to drive growth and innovation. Importantly, we highlight that none of AMZN's 10 most significant acquisitions have a clear tie to AI, with Kiva Systems, a robotics company AMZN acquired in 2012, as the likely closest match to a sizable AI acquisition. While AMZN has not historically relied on M&A to drive growth and innovation, we believe the perception that it is behind in AI is so strong and that the AI opportunity is so important that it could lead management to make a massive acquisition to support it.

Opportunity for Creator Advertising and Social Commerce Remains Massive, Driven by Content Creators. Global Social commerce is growing rapidly and is expected to be worth $2 trillion by 2026 with a projected 25% CAGR . We continue to believe that Creators will be a driving factor of social commerce, given that 30% of US social media users have purchased something after seeing an influencer or creator post about it . Ultimately, Creators will continue to drive advertising revenue for YouTube and Meta, as YouTube and Facebook remain the most widely used online platforms for adults. A survey conducted by PEW found that 84% of U.S. adults report using YouTube, compared to 71% for Facebook and 50% for Instagram. Notably, adults under 30 are more likely than older adults to use YouTube (95%), Instagram (80%), and TikTok (63%) platforms. While YouTube is the most widely used online platform among U.S. teens , it will likely retain almost all its younger users as they age.

Given the data, we believe that content creator marketing has moved past brand awareness and is part of the conversion funnel, making it vital for platforms to support creator monetization. According to HubSpot , 61% of consumers trust influencers' recommendations more than traditional ads, and 74% of Gen Z say they prefer discovering products through Creators (Statista, 2024), underscoring the significant opportunity for social media platforms.

Role of AI Generative Apps and Content Unlikely to be Disruptive. Despite the popularity of AI generation apps like OpenAI's Sora, Meta's Vibes, and Google's Nano Banana, consumers increasingly have a negative perception of generative AI (Gen AI) in the creator economy, as 32% of consumers saw Gen AI as a harmful disruptor, up from 18% in 2023 . Additionally, as of this year, ~26% of consumers prefer Gen AI content to traditional consumer content, down from 60% in 2023. Given consumer sentiment, we do not see Gen AI content as a headwind to the creator economy. Conversely, we believe that influencer marketing will become increasingly valued for its authenticity and ability to build trust with consumers.

YouTube is one of the most powerful ad platforms globally with +2.5B MAU, and we believe it is best positioned to benefit from ongoing dramatic shifts in the broader media landscape as users consume more short-form video. Management noted on the 2Q25 call that improvements in platform discoverability are attributable to AI, which we believe should help ensure Creator content growth remains healthy and better position both YouTube and Creators. Combined with news tools for creators to better monetize their content, 2026E is set up for strong revenue growth. Strong Potential for Growth from Shorts, Audience Reach, and Expansion. YouTube Shorts launched in the U.S. in March 2021 and globally in July of the same year. Alphabet launched YouTube Shorts to empower the next generation of mobile-first Creators. It allows users to share short videos on YouTube, a product that is similar to and competes with TikTok and Instagram Reels.

YouTube mentioned in June that Shorts Daily Active Views reached 200 billion (+186% relative to March 2024, 88% CAGR since 1Q22), which should unlock incremental ad loads given greater reach potential. Growth from 2024 to 2Q25 was likely driven by Google's revenue-share monetization offering for YouTube Shorts, which allows new and existing Creators in the YouTube Partner Program to become eligible for revenue sharing on ads viewed within Shorts in the Shorts Feed. The ad revenue share program likely drove a 186% increase in DAUs by incentivizing Creators to generate more content, creating a flywheel of higher engagement and, in turn, higher advertising revenue. Given creators' massive influence and platforms' ability to monetize, we remain bullish on YouTube, as it rewards its Creators, likely driving higher usage on the platform relative to its competitors.

Per Emarketer , YouTube accounted for the most U.S. Creator payouts in 2024, with Creators keeping 45% of the revenue, creating a strong incentive for more Creators to publish content on the platform. Exhibit 52 - YouTube Short DAUs in Billions Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports At the 2025 Made On YouTube event, the company announced various AI tools to streamline content launch for Creators, as well as multiple shopping and sponsored ad features for 2026. Ultimately, the new features should ensure Creator content growth remains healthy, positioning both YouTube and Creators on a path toward increased monetization. For 2026E, we estimate YouTube Ad revenue at roughly $40.7B (+14.2% YoY).

· Dynamic Sponsorship Ads for the Long-Form Video Format to Drive Higher Ad Revenue: The new format allows Creators to dynamically switch between brand-sponsored pop-ups on videos, allowing for more brand spots. Previously, Creators could only have one sponsored ad per video. This update is expected to drive higher ad revenue, as the format allows for more sponsored ads per video. It should also increase content on the platform as Creators will earn more from their videos, incentivizing more frequent content releases. We note that the product will begin testing in 2026E and is expected to help drive revenue growth throughout the year. · Shorts to Include External Links, Similar to TikTok: Creators can now add links to their Shorts. This will ultimately enable advertisers to understand brand traffic and conversions, potentially helping to drive higher CPMs for the platform. YouTube mentioned in June that Shorts' Daily Active Views are +186% relative to March 2024, with 200 billion daily views, which should unlock incremental ad loads given the greater reach potential.

· Bringing More Advertisers and Agencies onto YouTube with Creator Hub: The recently announced Creator Partnerships Hub, a tab within Google Ads, will help advertisers and agencies find and connect with Creators. · Supercharging YouTube Shopping with AI: Google's AI will now automatically identify and link products that are mentioned in videos. This should increase GMV, which the company notes has seen strong momentum on YouTube Shopping and has grown 5x year-over-year. · YouTube: Testing AI Overviews within Search: Announced in 2Q25, this is a natural extension of AI's revenue-generating capabilities, helping improve contextualization across videos and enhance content discovery for Creators. · YouTube Expands Data Sharing Between Creators and Brands: A greater data share between brands and Creators should improve targeting and expand reach for advertisers, effectively improving ROAS. The agreements eliminate friction, enabling creators and advertisers to work more effectively.

Exhibit 53 - YouTube Ad Revenue ($ in M) with BMO Estimates and YoY Growth (%) Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports Video Podcasting is a Rapidly Growing Format with YouTube Leading the Way. Consumer demand and viewing of video podcasts is enormous. In February, YouTube announced that more than 1 billion monthly active viewers consume podcast content on the platform, and over 400 million hours of podcasts were watched in 2024. Despite podcasts' origins as an audio medium, 72% of podcast listeners say they prefer shows with video, according to a study by Cumulus Media. YouTube is the preferred platform for 39% of podcast viewers and listeners, ahead of Spotify at 21%. We continue to believe YouTube will lead the video podcasting market, given it offers a higher ad revenue share ( Creators on YouTube keep 55% compared to Spotify, providing Creators a 50/50 split ) and a much larger audience base compared to Spotify's 700M users.

Source: BMO Capital Markets, eMarketer Exhibit 55 - Users Podcast Consumption by Platform Source: Cumulus Podcast Network, Sherwood News

Creators remain critical to Meta's apps, and we now project approximately $10.6 billion in payouts in 2025E (up from $9 billion previously), with upside potential to ensure effective content supply growth. Management noted that it continues to roll out new tools for Creators to ensure ongoing effective supply growth. While this is a net positive, the overall spending as a percentage of advertising revenue remains significantly lower than YouTube's, which could lead Creators to move off-platform. Meta Has Meaningful Tailwinds Ahead.... A recent check with our expert believes META growth could accelerate in 2026E primarily due to four key factors:

1. Meta will benefit from deeper monetization of its inventory through overlay ads on top of creator content, as 75% of Facebook/Instagram content is currently not monetized, and WhatsApp for Business. 2. Meta is best positioned to capture 50% of the decline in SEO spending. 3. The rollout of Meta Business AI, potentially in 1Q26E, is likely to drive higher SMB ad spending on the platform. 4. 2026E is expected to see a ramp in ad spend by Temu and Shein, following the two companies' pullback in 2025E due to tariff impacts. ....Though Beware of TikTok's Return and Financial Risks from Meta's Evolving Approach to Creator Payouts. We continue to view competitive threats from TikTok and YouTube, potential issues retaining Creator talent, and uncertainty around AI ROI as future challenges for the platform.

· Performance-Based Payouts per Creator Remain Low. Instagram is shifting from traditional revenue share to performance-based bonuses for content creators. While these bonuses are becoming more frequent, the majority of Creators (about 72% of 200 million globally) still earn less than $500 annually from their content. Recently, Instagram shut down a program allowing Creators to earn revenue from advertisements placed between content on their profiles , potentially reducing content and engagement on the app. · Potential Margin Headwind If Payout Model Changes. Meta is testing skippable ads on Instagram and could move to a traditional revenue share model (like YouTube's for long-form content), which could increase costs by $3-5 billion annually and risk burning free cash flow (FCF) before the program becomes profitable. The company is currently testing and iterating these models, especially for short-form video, where attribution and ROI are more challenging than for photos.

· Return of TikTok Likely to Impact 2026E. Meta's 2026E growth could face headwinds from TikTok, which could recapture ad spending lost primarily to Meta in 2025E. TikTok's advertisers shifted spending off the platform following the unknown status of the company operating in the U.S. With the likely upcoming durable return of the platform online, our expert estimates that TikTok's U.S. Ad revenue could grow from approximately $8B in 2025E to roughly $12-13B in 2026E (+56% YoY at midpoint). The shift in ad spending back to TikTok is expected to ramp up throughout 2026E, with the most significant impact on Meta and other platforms in 2H26E. · Video Competition from TikTok and YouTube. TikTok leads in short-term discoverability, while YouTube dominates long-form and is putting increasing pressure on Meta with YouTube Shorts. Pressure from the two platforms could push Meta to increase payouts to keep Creators in its ecosystem.

· ROI and AI Investment is Still Too Soon to Tell. Meta is investing heavily in AI to improve content recommendations and monetization, but the timing for a return on these investments remains uncertain. The company is balancing between rapid content success (like TikTok's 'For You' feed) and maintaining content quality. Additionally, after being hit with a €200M fine by EU regulators, META will now offer Facebook and Instagram users an alternative choice that shows fewer personalized ads and gives users the option to share less data in order to comply with the EU's Digital Markets Act. We note that in 3Q25, revenue from Europe contributed 25% to Meta's total advertising revenue and could be a potential headwind to 2026E growth.
