Regulation and Tech Advancements Drive Rise in Internet Age Verification: Increased regulatory focus and advancements in industry capabilities are driving increased age verification across the internet, as regulators look to keep users (specifically children) safe online. We highlight that the UK has passed an Online Safety Act aimed at driving online identity verification, as have Australia and other countries, as they look to leverage improvements in technology to force increased regulation around the internet, specifically adding guardrails around the content (and people) that children/minors can interact with online. One Thing For Sure: Online Verification Will Change The Internet Forever As these digital verification tools proliferate, we believe the Internet will change permanently, with some businesses, websites, and platforms seeing more severe impacts than others.

Notably, while some of these verification efforts will be driven by de-platforming users who should not be engaging with the content, we believe the need to provide facial ID and government ID verification could provide friction even for people who are allowed to view the content, as users will be less inclined to view/purchase certain content if they need to provide identification. Several companies within our coverage universe have recently discussed using age-verification tools to verify users' ages on their platforms.

3Q25 Call: "We're also aware that the new safety policies we're rolling out, consistent with our commitment to being the gold standard for safety, may cause some short-term friction with engagement and bookings, but ultimately, we think they will be a catalyst for long-term growth."

3Q25 Call: "We are also preparing for the upcoming rollout of platform-level age verification, which will use new signals provided by Apple, and soon Google, to help us better determine the age of our users and remove those we learn are under 13, or under 16 in certain geographies such as Australia. These actions are an essential step in maintaining a safe and compliant platform, though we expect they will also adversely affect engagement metrics as implementation progresses. In addition to these internal initiatives, we continue to experience the effects of regulation and government policy actions. Recent examples include Australia's Social Media Minimum Age Bill, which takes effect in December, and government restrictions on access to internet services in certain countries. We anticipate that similar regulations in other jurisdictions may take effect or be passed in the near future. These policy developments, combined with potential platform-level age verification, are likely to have negative impacts on user engagement metrics that we cannot currently predict."

3Q25 Call: "Building and maintaining that trust is core to our long-term success, which is why we're doubling down on trust and safety across our platforms. Nowhere is that more evident than at Tinder, where we're integrating safety directly into the product experience like never before. The centerpiece of this effort is Face Check, our new facial verification feature that helps confirm users are real and match their profile photos. It's now required for all new users in California, Colombia, Canada, India, Australia, and Southeast Asia, and will roll out to additional US states and countries in the coming months. Face Check sets a new standard for authenticity. Using only a short video selfie, it helps confirm a user is real and matches their profile photos. We built this technology with care, ensuring it delivers meaningful improvements to trust and safety, while keeping the user experience seamless. Early results are strong and reinforce our confidence in the long-term benefits to the broader ecosystem. We have seen a 60% reduction in user views of profiles later identified as bad actors and a 40% decrease in reports of bad actor activity.

Our ongoing optimization efforts have resulted in only a low single-digit impact on monthly active users and revenue in test markets, which lessens over time."

OpenAI uses age prediction to determine whether a user is over 18. If OpenAI believes a user is under 18, they apply an experience with extra content protections, including graphic and gory content, things that could risk harmful behavior, including sexual, romantic, or violent role play, and content that promotes extreme beauty standards. Character.AI is banning users under 18 from having open-ended chats with its AI. Character AI uses an in-house "age assurance model" to classify a user's age based on both first-party and third-party data.

Persona is one of the leading online identification companies, working with several leading online companies, including OpenAI, Reddit, Lyft, LinkedIn, and others. While Persona works with many players online, from a child safety perspective, its tools are also valuable to financial institutions, which can use them to stop fraud, theft, and other threats to financial services.

The image below walks through how age verification for Roblox's 152 million DAUs works: users provide a one-time facial scan showing both their side profile and a forward-facing image of their face. Based on these images, the age verification process can provide a rough estimate of the user's age. However, we question the effectiveness of a one-time facial age-estimation process, as bad actors are likely to use their access to minors to scan their faces during the one-time authorization process to present themselves as younger users. Instead, we believe facial age estimation and broader online identity may need to be used on a case-bycase basis, which will help eliminate one-time fraudulent verification processes but also introduce friction in the user experience. Exhibit 60 - Roblox Age Verification Process Source: Engadget

User-Generated Content (UGC) in gaming is when a gaming platform provides its broader user base and community with the tools needed to build their own games on the platform. Through the platform's tools, users can build their own games, with their own maps and rules, creating truly new, custom gaming experiences. After users create their game, they can include monetization hooks, which allow the platform to keep a portion of those sales and pay out a portion to the UGC game Creator. The essence of UGC gaming reminds us of social platforms where content creators create user-generated content that is then monetized by the platform, with revenue shared with the Creators.

We expect User-Generated-Content (UGC) to be a key theme in the video game industry in 2026, as leading gaming platforms look to lean more into the opportunity following the success of Roblox in 2025. We remind investors that UGC in gaming has been around for decades, as many games have always offered users tools to create unique experiences and mini-games within existing gaming ecosystems. As an example, think about custom games in the early days of Halo, in which players were given the tools and ability to edit maps and create specific game rules, allowing them to create their own experience in a custom version of the game. However, UGC has made meaningful strides since then , as platforms like RBLX have taken the opportunity to a new level by lowering the barrier to game development, allowing anyone to build a robust gaming experience. We highlight that 2025E is shaping up to be a breakout year for RBLX and the UGC opportunity, with RBLX expected to grow its Bookings by 50% YoY to $6.5B, giving it ~3% of the global video game market.

Exhibit 61 - RBLX Bookings (in $M) and YoY Bookings Growth Source: BMO Capital Markets, FactSet Roblox has already Scaled a Massive UGC Creator Community We highlight that RBLX has already done the most challenging part of creating a successful UGC gaming platform, scaling the developer base. We believe a large developer base is the most critical part of the puzzle, as it incentivizes users to come to the platform to play the games Creators have made. This, in turn, creates a flywheel in which more players on the platform drive more and higher-quality developers to make games on the platform, which leads to more players and so on. RBLX has provided historical disclosures about its developer base, and in 2023, it offered a funnel that showed the breadth and depth of its UGC developer base.

In 2023, RBLX had 5 million Creators on the platform earning payouts, with over 12,700 earning over $1,000 a year, 96 earning over $1M a year, and 9 developers or Creators earning over $10M a year. We believe these numbers have only continued to grow meaningfully over the last two years. Exhibit 62 - Breakdown of Developer and Creator Rewards / Engagement Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports

Epic has already signaled they are leaning into UGC with Fortnite - We discussed this theme at length in our UGC developer economics deep dive . In our note, we highlight the meaningful economic incentive Epic Games is offering to UGC game developers to encourage them to build their next hit game on the RBLX platform. Importantly, Epic Games recently highlighted that Fortnite has scaled to 100M MAUs, with 40% of playtime going to UGC, where UGC developers earn "hundreds of millions of dollars a year" from their content. For perspective, we highlight that 100% of playtime on Roblox is spent on user-generated content, with Roblox's 152M DAUs helping developers on the platform generate $1.5B+ annually. Exhibit 63 - Fornite UGC Earnout Change vs. RBLX Estimate Source: Fortnite

Epic Games Leaned in Further to UGC Through a Recently Announced Partnership with Unity: Unity and Epic Games announced a partnership on November 19, 2025 , in which they will bring Unity games into the Fortnite ecosystem. As a result, developers will be able to publish Unity games on Fortnite and participate in the Fortnite Creator Economy, ultimately broadening Fortnite's scale in the UGC gaming opportunity. We wrote about this extensively in our note here . We Suspect GTA VI Will Include a UGC Component: We believe the upcoming launch of GTA VI in November 2026 will help to serve as TTWO's entry point into the UGC space. We remind investors that TTWO acquired FiveM in August 2023, which, at the time, was essentially doing unlicensed UGC on the GTA V ecosystem. We believe they acquired FiveM after sending them a cease-and-desist order, as they realized there was a real economic opportunity to support UGC environments in GTA.

As a result, we believe GTA VI will serve as a meaningful entry point for TTWO into the UGC space and will be underpinned by their acquisition of FiveM. We believe GTA's positioning as a mature-rated game with a massive open-world environment presents an attractive opportunity for UGC developers to build unique UGC experiences in a gigantic, high-fidelity sandbox.

Importantly, while we believe RBLX has a meaningful head start in scaling a UGC-driven business, we expect competition to meaningfully ramp in 2026 ( Fortnite , GTA VI , etc.). While we expect RBLX to maintain its leadership position in UGC in 2026, we believe that ramping competition could pose a risk to its longer-term opportunity as competitors scale their offerings. However, we believe one thing is clear: the UGC opportunity in gaming is likely still in its early innings, and its proliferation has the potential to change the long-term growth outlook for the broader video game industry. RBLX Alone Represents a $1.5B+ Annual Opportunity for UGC Developers: The economic incentive is clear for UGC game developers, as RBLX has scaled to a $6B+ in Bookings business that offers a $1.5B+ (and growing) economic earn-out opportunity for developers on its platform.

We believe this massive pool of developer payments serves as something of a moat for Roblox in the near term, as we expect UGC game developers to focus on platforms that offer the most significant economic payout opportunity, which we believe is clearly Roblox today. Exhibit 64 - RBLX Developer Exchnage (DexEx) Fees and DevEx as a Percent of Bookings RBLX is $1B Economic Opportunity for UGC Developers Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports, FactSet Scale Matters in UGC: We believe scale is the most critical factor in any UGC opportunity, as UGC creators will focus on platforms with the largest user bases and payout pools, offering the most significant economic opportunity. In gaming, that scaled platform is clearly RBLX, whose 152M DAUs is ~50% larger than Fortnite's ~100M MAUs. Exhibit 65 - RBLX DAUs vs. Fortnite MAUs (in M) Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports

Similar to most other Internet verticals, online travel has experienced a material transformation in 2025. On the one hand, consumer preferences continue to shift towards experiences (with related travel), and travel decisions are increasingly influenced by social media, while on the other hand, technology, and AI in particular, is profoundly reshaping the user experience. Over the past several years, travel has benefited from a long-term trend in consumer preferences that we expect to continue unfolding in the immediate future. A multi-decade shift is underway as consumer preferences have moved away from material possessions towards experiences and live events, with an accompanying increase in travel or experience tourism. With several major sporting events in 2026 - including the 2026 Winter Olympics/Paralympics and the 2026 FIFA World Cup - we expect this shift to gain further momentum, with travel remaining a significant beneficiary.

A long-term structural trend is underway, with consumers increasingly prioritizing experiences and live events over material possessions. · Shift in Spending Patterns: Consumer spending on experiences is projected to account for 32% of U.S. discretionary expenditures by 2030, up from 22% in 1985. · Resilient Demand Despite Inflation: Even with stickier-than-expected inflation, consumers continue to favor out-of-home entertainment. As of 3Q25, 46% of consumers plan to maintain current spending over the next three months, and 18% expect to increase spending. Exhibit 66 - U.S. Consumer Discrentionary Spend Over the Next 3 Months (3Q25), Compared to Usual, for Entertainment Away From Home Source: BMO Capital Markets, McKinsey Analyzing spending in experiences across age groups, millennial and Gen Z consumers are increasingly prioritizing spending on live events over traditional financial goals, such as saving or purchasing a home.

According to McKinsey, 19% of surveyed consumers globally plan to cut back in non-discretionary categories while splurging in discretionary areas, which represents a clear benefit for the online travel ecosystem. Gen Z's spending is growing at twice the rate of previous generations at the same age and is on track to surpass the global expenditures of baby boomers by 2029. By 2035, Gen Z is expected to contribute an additional $8.9 trillion to the worldwide economy, reinforcing the long-term demand for live experiences and related travel, positioning online travel to capture significant growth.

Intent to splurge; 02 2025, % of respondents Source: McKinsey As the shift towards experiences unfolds, the importance of travel in consumers' lives remains high. According to research conducted in February and early March 2025 for Expedia's 2025 Traveler Value Index, drawing on insights from over 11,000 consumers across 11 global markets, travel remains a top priority, with 50% of consumers saying it is more vital now than five years ago. Further underscoring travel's enduring importance is the finding that 88% of consumers planned to take a leisure trip in the following 12 months, and 68% were likely to book international travel - a 19% increase since 2022 - despite ongoing politico-economic uncertainties.

At the same time, discovery and demand creation in travel are moving upstream to mobile super-apps, creator-led social, and AI assistants, compressing the planning-to-booking cycle and rewarding closedloop, data-rich environments. Social discovery and influencer commerce are becoming increasingly more important in travel at the upper end of the funnel. Another set of insights from Expedia's 2025 Traveler Value Index survey shows that travelers are increasingly turning to social media for trip inspiration: · 61% said they find trip ideas on platforms, up from 35% in 2022, and · 73% said influencer recommendations have swayed their decision to book a trip or travel component. Importantly, younger travelers, particularly those under 40, are more strongly influenced by social media, with 84% reporting that influencer recommendations have affected their booking decisions.

Similarly, independent industry research also shows the increased importance of social media in travel, indicating it influences destination choices more than traditional media or even friends and family. But it also shows that social media's ability to convert and monetize these inspirations into actual bookings is coming short. According to Skift's State of Travel 2025 report, roughly 60% of travelers say they feel comfortable booking through social channels. However, the actual conversion rate remains relatively low, estimated at under 10% by Sabre. This should not be surprising, given the higher complexity and higher price tag associated with travel purchases.

We believe that AI will be the technology that shortens, if not eliminates, the monetization gap between inspiration and bookings. We are already seeing how AI-powered inspiration and Generative Engine Optimization (GEO) are reshaping the playing field in travel. As consumers get more comfortable with AI assistants and tools, we believe that AI-native capabilities will become critical in the travel industry. Not surprisingly, a March 2025 survey by Deloitte revealed a 50% increase in AI-assisted trip planning, with 15% of travelers reporting using Gen AI tools, up from 10% in 2024. And once again, millennial and Gen Z travelers were the age groups reporting the highest AI-assisted trip-planning usage - both at 23%.

A more recent consumer survey by McKinsey , conducted in June - July 2025, indicates even higher growth in the use of Gen AI for trip planning. It shows that the share of consumers who use ChatGPT and similar tools extensively to plan any aspect of their trip has more than doubled over the past year, increasing from 13% in 2024 to 30% in 2025E.

Use of ChatGPT or a similar Al-based app to assist in planning any aspect of your trip, % of respondents Source: McKinsey, Skift US Travel Tracker Survey, Jun-Jul 2025, n = 1,002

Agentic AI Becomes the New Operating System in Travel We think that multilingual chatbots, AI assistants, natural-language search, and AI-assisted trip planning are only the beginning. In 2026, we expect current consumer-facing AI tools to evolve from planning concierge-type into end-to-end transacting agents linked to first-party identity-rich data and loyalty wallets. We also see AI-powered real-time personalization becoming a competitive moat. Ultimately, we expect agentic AI to become the new operating system in travel - from discovery to booking to on-destination servicing. Online travel should remain one of the biggest beneficiaries of new AI capabilities Over the past 12 months, AI chatbots have significantly improved customer service levels across the industry with faster and more accurate query responses.

At the same time, listing creation has noticeably improved with AI image models and tools that enhance listing quality for hosts, improving descriptions and the overall customer experience. From a P&L perspective, we see early operational efficiencies with a measurable impact from the broader adoption of AI. Looking ahead, personalization capabilities will remain a tailwind for supply and demand, and next-gen AI solutions will increasingly surface the right product to the right traveler at the right time. In other words, users will discover destinations they had never thought of visiting before. We expect the platforms to increasingly cross-sell across their offerings to ensure a high-quality user experience. As a result, we believe the path from discovery to booking will continue to shorten.

Consumers are entering 2026 with mixed macro signals - price increases have moderated but remain elevated, hiring has cooled, but wage growth on average is positive in real terms. Survey-based confidence is weak even as card networks report solid spending. As a result, a K-shaped economy is emerging, with the top 10-20% of consumers - supported by asset wealth - largely shrugging off mid-single-digit inflation. In comparison, middle America feels the impact of 30% cumulative post-pandemic price increases despite recent real wage gains. We are also seeing non-prime borrowers increasingly relying on credit to maintain spending, signaling greater financial strain among vulnerable households. Younger generations are facing disproportionate financial pressure too, with total monthly debt payments up 20% for millennials and 27% for Gen Z, outpacing both inflation and wage growth.

As a result, all income groups are adopting a value-first playbook - making more frequent trips with smaller baskets and embracing private label brands, with retailers like Walmart seeing grocery private brand penetration rise 60 basis points year-over-year. Lower- and middle-income households are aggressively cutting discretionary spending and relying heavily on discounters and extreme-value programs, while high-income consumers maintain premium purchases but increasingly shop at value-focused retailers. Consumer spending is shifting toward essentials, with retail food and beverage dollars rising while discretionary general merchandise declining, and grocers reporting significant trade-down within categories. We note that payment networks report resilient spending in the U.S. despite consumer sentiment hitting its second-lowest point on record in November, per recent University of Michigan data.

The Fed's preferred gauge shows inflation is stabilizing but still above target - the core PCE price index (ex-food and energy) rose 2.8% year-over-year in September, vs. +2.9% in August, +2.9% in July, and +2.8% in June. However, September headline inflation inched higher to +2.8% year-over-year, vs. +2.7% in August, +2.6% in July, and +2.6% in June. Trade policy is feeding through to goods, with increasing evidence that tariffs are adding stickiness to goods inflation, which is being passed through to consumers, with expectations for continued impact in 2026. Labor market momentum cooled through late summer and continued to slow down in September as three-month job gains (July-September) totaled 62,000 and the unemployment rate rose to 4.4%, the highest in four years. While not a sharp contraction, the deceleration and layoff headlines are visible to consumers and weigh on sentiment.

The Atlanta Fed's tracker shows nominal wage growth running near 4.1%, implying modest real gains against roughly 3% inflation, supported by BLS reporting real average hourly earnings increasing 0.8% year-over-year in September. However, the personal saving rate remains subdued at ~4.7% (September), limiting the capacity to absorb shocks for lower-income households.

At the same time, Equifax identified a widening strain for non-prime borrowers, with the share of bankcard debt held by this group surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Their total bankcard balances rose 135% from May 2021 to May 2025, versus 54% for all borrowers, signaling greater reliance on revolving credit among vulnerable households. CFPB data show BNPL adoption surged, too, with approvals rising and deep-subprime/subprime borrowers comprising a large share of originations. Late payments are common (roughly 41% of users report a late payment), and loan stacking is frequent, increasing near-term payment risk for lower-credit consumers.

According to the latest University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index, consumer confidence in November 2025 reached its lowest level since June 2022 and the second-lowest level on record (back to 1952). Preliminary results for December show that the Index improved 2.3 pts sequentially, but it has been declining year-over-year since the start of 2025. Exhibit 69 - Consumer Sentiment Index and YoY and MoM Change - * December 2025 preliminary results Source: University of Michigan, BMO Capital Markets Similarly, the Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell 6.8 points in November to a 7-month low of 88.7. Both the assessment of the present situation (down 4.3 points to a 14-month low of 126.9) and expectations (down 8.6 points, 4th drop in a row, to a 7-month low of 63.2) took a hit, with the latter below the recession-signal threshold of 80 for the tenth straight month.

In contrast, payment networks report resilient spending in the U.S. , at least through September. Visa's payments volume (both debit and credit) grew 8% year-over-year in F4Q25 (ending Sep 30), with higher-spending cardholders driving a larger share of growth. Management also reiterated broad-based strength across categories and channels in 4Q25E, while acknowledging rising uncertainty. Mastercard similarly cited healthy consumer spending in 3Q25, amid a generally supportive macroeconomic environment, including fairly steady inflation and well-balanced labor markets. The company saw U.S. payments volume (both debit and credit) grow 7% year-over-year in 3Q25.

As a result, consumer spend is tilting toward essentials and value-driven baskets, with retail food and beverage dollars up and discretionary general merchandise down, signaling a durable mix shift. Affluent-led discretionary resilience remains evident in travel and digital commerce, with Visa noting the highest spend band continues to grow fastest, travel improved sequentially, and U.S. eCommerce is expanding faster than in-store spend. Holiday trackers corroborate eCommerce outperformance and sustained restaurant demand during peak events. Notable mix shifts driven by changing consumer behavior include: · Food-at-home gaining share - retail food and beverage dollars rose while discretionary general merchandise declined. · Home-related categories are showing momentum online - furniture is forecast to grow, and consumers are upgrading home items on deal days. · Travel remains resilient - cross-border volumes improved, with top-spend cohorts leading growth.

· Restaurants grew 4.5% on Black Friday, reflecting demand for experiences. · Grocers see private labels outperform national brands amid elevated promotions and commodity pressures, underscoring broad trade-down dynamics. · Club retailers report a record in own-brand penetration as members seek value. · Mass/discount formats and superstores are taking share, fueling a surge in store-brand SKUs.

As retailers clear their safety stock, accumulated earlier in the year in anticipation of announced tariffs, newly-sourced inventory is expected to hit margins. We believe larger players will try to press suppliers to absorb part of these costs, while smaller vendors struggle to re-source, narrowing assortment. Industry experts suggest ~80% tariff pass-through to consumer prices. Given that, we don't think this is a good setup for retail sales heading into 2026, especially since consumers continue to cite the burden of high prices as a significant concern. As a result, we expect overall consumer trends observed in 2H25 to continue into 2026 and potentially accelerate if the macro picture deteriorates. Still, stress should remain concentrated in lower-income and near-prime cohorts, while the affluent-cohort spend remains resilient. We also expect off-price models to capture a bigger share of consumers' wallets.

That said, we expect lower-income consumers, most of whom are exposed to shelter/rent shocks that crowd out non-essential spending, to increase their use of dollar-value channels. For middle-income consumers, we expect to see broad value-seeking and selective pullbacks in discretionary spend, with home purchases increasingly timed to promotions. Lastly, we expect high-income consumers to sustain their elevated level of spending, particularly on travel and experiences, while favoring club and online channels.

Below, we walk through our predictions from our 2025 outlook and grade ourselves on our performance.

We are still in the early innings of the AI wave Following the November 2022 release of ChatGPT, the tech industry (and most industries) has reoriented its priorities toward AI business opportunities and internal cost efficiencies. We believe that the last three years (2023-2025) have been centered around foundational model development, in which leading model providers like OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and xAI have invested tens of billions of dollars to build powerful AI models that can support a range of business and consumer applications to be built on top of them. While apps have been developed over the last several years (ChatGPT, Replit, Windsurf, Cursor, Hebbia, and others), we believe this is only the start of the AI app build-out, and the next few years will be defined by AI productization and applications. As a result, we expect inference spend within cloud computing environments to meaningfully scale as these applications are built and gain consumer and enterprise adoption, as AI-driven token spend ultimately drives datacenter inference costs.

AI Adoption Remains Early as Most Enterprises are Still in the Testing Phase - According to a November 2025 State of AI report from McKinsey , the AI opportunity remains very early in its penetration of the enterprise. In their survey, only 7% of respondents suggested that AI has been fully deployed and integrated across their entire organizations, with 31% saying it is "scaling", 30% saying they are "piloting", and 32% still "experimenting". We believe this early adoption cycle underscores that we are still in the early innings of the broader AI opportunity, as we expect every enterprise to have fully scaled AI solutions across their organization when the AI opportunity reaches maturity. AWS and GCP remain well-positioned to benefit from the ongoing shift in IT spending to the Cloud. AI workload growth will continue for the next several years, with AWS and GCP net beneficiaries. We believe Cloud providers with best-in-class full-stack gen AI offerings will garner incremental Cloud dollars.

Phase of Organization's Use of AI, by Company Revenues, % of Respondents Source: BMO Capital Markets, McKinsey Looking ahead to 2026, we expect companies to accelerate their internal AI spend, which should continue to improve productivity and limit the potential for headcount cost creep. In other words, companies will continue trading OpEx for CapEx in the upcoming year. Given this backdrop, we see stable-to-growing wallet-share gains for both AWS and GCP in 2026 and beyond.

The picks-and-shovels providers (NVDA, AWS, Azure, GCP) have been clear early beneficiaries of the AI build-out, as their offerings are the foundation-level tools that enable businesses to pursue the AI opportunity. We believe these companies are likely to continue to benefit from the AI opportunity as model providers continue to aggressively train foundational models on top of cloud providers and application builders build apps that will sit on top of cloud providers.

While access to high-performance GPUs from NVIDIA has been a key constraint on scaling AI, we believe we are starting to shift from hardware-related bottlenecks to energy-related bottlenecks, as cloud providers struggle to find sufficient power capacity to support their infrastructure build-out. We highlight that on the 3Q25 earnings call, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy stated: "So, we're bringing in quite a bit of capacity. Today, overall in the industry, maybe the bottleneck is power. I think at some point, it may move to chips, but we're bringing in quite a bit of capacity. And as fast as we're bringing it in right now, we are monetizing it."

We are starting to see meaningful accelerations in some cloud vendor backlogs as a result of companies signing massive multi-year contracts with cloud providers. · ORCL (covered by BMO analyst Keith Bachman) was among the first to see a massive backlog growth following a $300B/5-year contract with OpenAI, leading to a significant sequential increase in its backlog. · We have since seen GOOGL experience a similar (though smaller) acceleration, as they signed more $1B+ deals between 1Q25-3Q25 than in all of 2023 and 2024 combined. In 3Q25, GOOGL's backlog accelerated to 79% YoY growth, accelerating meaningfully from 37% growth in 2Q25.

· While AMZN's YoY backlog growth actually decelerated in 3Q25, management noted that it did not include several unannounced new deals in October, which, combined, are more than the total deal volume observed in 3Q, suggesting that AMZN is set up for a meaningful acceleration in 4Q25 backlog growth. Notably, only a few days after these comments, AMZN also signed $38 billion, 7year deal to support OpenAI, suggesting backlog growth could be even more robust. In short, we believe that strong, ramping backlog growth should support strong growth in the cloud industry over the next several years.

Primarily related to GCP Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports

There are Three Core Layers to The Cloud: IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS are the key layers to the cloud offering, which stand for Infrastructure as a Service, Platform as a Service, and Software as a Service, in which customers can purchase these products as an ongoing subscription service rather than having to make capital-intensive purchases.

IaaS: Infrastructure as a Service provides customers with core cloud resources such as storage, compute, networking, and virtualization, allowing them to benefit from a datacenter without owning or managing the day-to-day operations. Additionally, customers can flex their usage up and down to meet their specific needs, which is essential for those with seasonal spikes in compute needs, as they cannot just rent additional capacity when needed and leave it idle for the majority of the year when they do not need it. PaaS: Platform as a Service involves the delivery and management of both the hardware and software resources to develop apps through the cloud. Customers using PaaS can create, run, and manage their apps without maintaining the infrastructure that supports them.

SaaS: Software as a Service is the application stack in which user-facing products and applications are delivered to an end user in a cloud-based environment. SaaS products are typically paid for on a recurring revenue model in which a user pays the application owner a monthly or annual fee to access the software, and the app is typically run through a web browser, eliminating the need for the end user to download/install software directly onto their device. SaaS to Remain The Largest Portion of Cloud Market: The SaaS portion of the cloud is expected to remain the most significant contributor to the broader cloud market, as it directly supports revenuegenerating applications for businesses.

Primarily related to AWS Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports Exhibit 74 - Breakdown of the Broader Cloud Market (in $B) Source: Gartner, BMO Capital Markets IaaS to Remain the Fastest Growing Part of the Cloud Market: Infrastructure as a Service is expected to be the fastest growing component of the cloud, as hyperscalers continue to deeply invest behind building out the infrastructure that will allow them to support AI applications at scale. Exhibit 75 - Cloud Market Growth by Segement Source: Gartner, BMO Capital Markets AWS remains a leader in Cloud services, with significant AI capabilities We show the market share of IaaS, which indicates that it is a formidable player across IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS categories. IDC defines public cloud infrastructure as a service that aggregates compute, raw, ephemeral, and persistent storage capacity, along with the associated network capabilities, delivered through a public cloud deployment model.

Furthermore, we show the SaaS/PaaS market share, highlighting a more fragmented market (62% share for long-tail cloud providers versus 17.7% for IaaS). Amazon will see significant tailwinds from accelerating IT spending, shifting to the Cloud, and incremental AI workloads. Specifically, AWS offers Trainium / Inferentia in addition to Nvidia chips, Bedrock for clients looking to scale LLM capabilities, and Q/Rufus at the application layer. Bedrock offers users the broadest model selection and continues to improve its offering by onboarding more leading models, giving customers a choice of the foundational model that is best for them. Given advanced code generation, visual analysis, and complex customer queries, Claude's models resonate very well with customers. For example, at re:Invent 2024, one session highlighted that DoorDash leverages Claude to power its customer solution center, thereby lowering response times.

Furthermore, Anthropic announced that computer use is in public beta, which allows Claude to perform tasks by interpreting and understanding screenshots and automatically adjusting the necessary computer commands. - · Specific use cases for computers include automated software testing with graphical user interfaces and integrations with software or apps that do not offer API access. In addition, automating repetitive tasks requiring UI interactions and onboarding, and supporting UI systems. In addition, Prompt Management and fine-tuning features are also gaining user adoption. Separately, SageMaker helps prepare data for AI training and deploy it into production. SageMaker Studio helps developers create models. The user accepts 37% of the code written by Amazon Q, as the tool has helped to write +200k lines of code into production. A case study with NAB showed that code recommendations achieved a 50% acceptance rate, driving a 40%+ productivity improvement.

That said, with 'hundreds of thousands' of customers running AI/ML workloads on AWS, significant adoption potential remains ahead - AWS noted during 3Q24 in October that its AI business is growing in the triple-digit percentages Y/Y. Impressively, we highlight that AWS is already executing AI at scale for enterprise customers, as they underscored at re:Invent 2025 that they have over 50 customers who are processing over 1 trillion tokens on AWS, which is higher than the October 2025 disclosure from OpenAI when they said they have 30 customers processing over 1T tokens. We believe this underscores the massive AI business AWS has already built, with 50+ customers relying on it to run their scaled AI workloads. More broadly, AWS is heavily leveraging AI internally in its business, having built 21k agents since July 2025 and seeing AI automation deliver $2B+ in annual cost savings, which we expect will meaningfully increase over time. Exhibit 76 - AMZN Generative AI Value Chain

Source: Amazon.com, BMO Capital Markets GCP's TPUs offer significant cost advantages and attractive performance for customers looking to expand beyond NVIDIA With +160 models, Vertex AI solutions offer clients significant scale opportunities given 1P, open-source, and 3P model integrations. In late November, GCP introduced new capabilities to help developers build effective apps on the Vertex AI platform. The output is continued client growth and greater spending among existing clients, bringing their products into production. TensorFlow is a free, open-source software library for various machine learning and artificial intelligence tasks, including deep learning, neural networks, natural language processing, and computer vision. It has become a leading ML framework, widely adopted by researchers, developers, and businesses for building, training, and deploying ML models across various platforms and devices. In other words, TensorFlow enables collaboration and communication between research and engineering teams, which, combined with the open-source library, facilitates expedited product rollouts across all businesses.

TPUs are designed to enable Google AI to operate on devices as they can handle higher-performance computation. These chips also support video rendering, gameplay, HDR photo editing, and language translation. When combined with Google's 20+ years of ML/AI innovation, we believe this positions the company well to benefit from next-generation AI solutions internally and externally. GOOGL's TPUs Continue to See Meaningful Improvements with Each Generation: The Ironwood TPU generation (7th generation) represents a meaningful improvement from its prior generation, with 4x better performance per chip for both training and inference workloads vs the last generation. Ironwood can scale up to 9,216 chips in a superpod. Additionally, as highlighted in the chart below, Ironwood TPU has a TFlops/Watt ratio of 29.3x, up meaningfully from 14.6x/5.2x in the prior two generations, respectively, underscoring the power efficiency of TPUs and their continued advancements.

Exhibit 79 - GOOGL TPUs Peak Flops Per Watt Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports Thomas Kurian and the GCP management team continue to execute well. The company is rolling out new products built on more than 20 years of AI investment. In September, GCP enabled AI customers with fine-tuning capabilities and model customization offerings. We believe these solutions offer clients a unique opportunity that competitors will find difficult to replicate.

While Google has been receiving credit for its own custom chip initiatives, we also highlight that Amazon has similarly been investing in the opportunity, as it continues to scale adoption of its Trainium and Inferentia hardware. Notably, we highlight that Amazon recently opened a new datacenter called "Project Rainier" , a purpose-built facility dedicated to servicing Anthropic. Importantly, we highlight that this datacenter houses 500k Trainium2 chips, as Anthropic plans to scale to more than 1 million chips by the end of 2025 (for both training and inference), underscoring Amazon's own success in custom silicon. Impressively, before the opening of this datacenter in 4Q25, management highlighted on the 3Q25 earnings call that Trainium2 is a multi-billion-dollar business that grew 150% sequentially.

While we believe GOOGL's TPU architecture is superior to Amazon's Trainium and Inferentia, we do think it offers a similar value prop to customers who want a more energy and cost-efficient way to train and run AI models. We believe both Amazon and Google will benefit from the same trends and should benefit as they scale their offerings over time. Further, AMZN has brought Trainium3 to general availability, as the new generation of chips delivers 4.4x more compute performance, 4x greater energy efficiency, and 4x the memory bandwidth vs its predecessor. Additionally, AWS has already begun work on Trainium4, which it expects will deliver a massive leap over Trainium3, with 6x better FP4, 4x memory bandwidth, and 2x memory capacity, as AWS continues to iterate on its tech stack at an impressive rate.

GOOGL has seen a meaningful re-rating in its valuation in 2H25 as it delivered an impressive beat in 3Q25 and successfully launched Gemini 3 to the top of LMArena. As a result, shares went from trading at a meaningful discount to the 10-year average of 21.5x to a meaningful premium, now trading at 28.5x. We believe the introduction of modern-day AI will bring about generational changes across every business and industry, as the integration of AI tools drives business efficiency and introduces new AIdriven product offerings. Broadly, we believe that over the long term, AI will help deliver both top-line revenue synergies and bottom-line efficiency through reduced variable costs and fixed-cost leverage. Notably, we expect AI to help unlock personalization at scale, helping companies to increasingly convert customers, likely with higher frequency and a lower customer acquisition cost. GOOGL and AMZN remain the best-positioned players in our coverage universe to benefit from AI -We strongly believe that GOOGL and AMZN are not only the best-positioned vendors in our coverage universe to win in AI over time, but we think they're also some of the clearest winners in any industry.

Notably, we highlight that their respective cloud units (GCP and AWS) are some of the most clear-cut ROI investments in the AI space, as investments (CapEx) into AI become immediately utilized in the cloud business as AI natives (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.) and others look to rent out access to GPU capacity to train models and run inference at scale. GOOGL AI Fears are Receding as Investors Realize GOOGL is an AI Winner -A core debate around GOOGL has focused on the proliferation of AI, and whether GOOGL was most at risk of AI-driven disruption, or if they are well-suited to benefit from the integration of AI.

For years now, bears have argued that GOOGL's crown jewel asset (Google Search) is at risk of AI-based disruption as users turn to AI chatbots (like ChatGPT) instead of searching on Google. While bears have pushed this narrative for well over 2 years, we have yet to find any evidence that this is true, as we perceive AI-based search to be more incremental to the core-search experience than cannibalistic. Said another way, we believe consumers are using generative AI-type search experiences for things they would never search for on Google or another search engine, creating an opportunity that is truly incremental rather than cannibalistic. Notably, we pulled DAU (Daily Active Users) data for Google, Gemini, and ChatGPT to compare user engagement across the three apps. The results were interesting, as they showed that the ChatGPT app has ~400M DAUs, meaningfully larger than the 60M DAUs that Gemini has scaled to.

However, we highlight that Google has over 2B DAUs in its app. While many perceive Gemini as a direct competitor to ChatGPT, we believe the integration of AI overviews into the core Google Search product makes Google a direct competitor to it.

- 500 1,000 1,500 2,000 2,500 Google ChatGPT Gemini Source: Sensortower, BMO Capital Markets To prove our thesis, we have conducted two consumer surveys on their search habits and how they might change over time. We ran our first survey of 1,000 consumers in August 2024 , and followed it up with a rerun in May 2025 to see how respondents' views had changed. The results were surprising (and clear): GOOGL users reported meaningful positive experiences with Google's AI overviews, with 49% reporting a positive experience vs 7% negative (and 44% neutral), implying a 42-point gap between those with a positive view and those with a negative view. Notably, users also suggested that AI overviews are leading them to click more links, with a 10-point gap between those who say AI overviews are making them click more and those who say they are making them click less.

Lastly, we were impressed by the comparison from our August 2024 survey versus our May 2025 survey, in which 85% of users called Google their primary search destination (up 200bps from August 2024), and a meaningful increase in the percentage of Google users who said they are unlikely to stop using Google search as their primary search engine. While bears will continue to say that Google is going to lose share in search, we highlight that our survey, as well as recent financial results, underscores our view that Google is actually best positioned to win in AI-related search, supported by: 1. Existing product leadership (Google); 2. AI product leadership.

As AI adoption continues to proliferate, several companies in our coverage universe have made disclosures (often one-off) that underscore the benefits they are seeing in AI.

During the 3Q earnings release, management gave the following stats related to their AI business: · As of 3Q25, AMZN had added 3.8GW of capacity over the LTM, and has doubled its capacity since 2022 · AMZN now plans to double the capacity again by the end of 2027, implying a 4x increase in capacity from 2022 to 2027 · Trainium2 is a multi-billion-dollar business, and grew 150% sequentially in 3Q25 · While the AWS backlog only grew 22% YoY in 3Q, management highlighted that they signed several large deals in October that were not included in the backlog number, and then signed the $38B OpenAI deal, suggesting AMZN could be set for a meaningful 4Q25E backlog number.

During the 3Q25 earnings release management provided the following stats related to their AI business: · GCP enterprise AI products are generating "billions in quarterly revenue. · GOOGL has signed more $1B+ cloud deals YTD (1Q25-3Q25) than they have in the last 2 years combined · Gemini App has over 650M MAUs (vs. 450M MAUs in 2Q25) as queries increased 3x sequentially. · Google has processed over 1.3 quadrillion monthly tokens, up 20x YoY. · Google also highlighted that its first-party models (such as Gemini) are currently processing 7B tokens per minute through its direct API, which is above the 6B tokens per minute that OpenAI recently reported at its second-ever OpenAI DevDay 2025 event, only a couple of weeks prior.

During the 3Q25 earnings release, management gave the following stats related to their AI business: · Advantage+ has scaled to a $60B ARR business · Lattice unified architecture: roll-out to app ads drove a roughly 3% increase in conversion. · Andromeda performance improvement: 14% increase in ad quality on Facebook surfaces was achieved by combining retrieval and early-stage ranking models. · Runtime model innovations: New ad ranking model in pilot saw a +2% increase in conversion on Instagram. · Recommendation system improvements: Surfacing 2x as many same-day published Reels vs. the start of the year. Instagram's expansion to broader topic diversity follows the success of the approach on Facebook and should continue to drive engagement.

Snapchat's AI disclosure is a bit more unique, as a company that is not actively investing in the AI opportunity. However, SNAP did announce one of the more unique AI integrations and partnerships we have seen thus far. · SNAP signed a 1-year deal with Perplexity, under which SNAP will integrate Perplexity's AIpowered answer engine into Snapchat, providing SNAP's ~1B MAUs with an AI-driven search experience directly integrated into the Snapchat app. ○ As a result, Perplexity will pay Snap $400M over one year (combination of cash and equity), with contributions beginning in 2026E.

Over the past year, we have written extensively on the ongoing hyperscaler CapEx cycle, which began in 2024 and will likely extend through at least 2027E. Google, Amazon, and Meta have all recently commented on the directional trajectory of their CapEx spend. Below we highlight some of the key commentary from management around each company's respective CapEx spend into 2026.

"With respect to CapEx, in the third quarter, our CapEx was $24 billion. The vast majority of our CapEx was invested in technical infrastructure with approximately 60% of that investment in servers and 40% in data centers and networking equipment... We're continuing to invest aggressively due to the demand we're experiencing from Cloud customers as well as the growth opportunities we see across the company. We now expect CapEx to be in the range of $91 billion to $93 billion in 2025, up from our previous estimate of $85 billion keeping in mind that the timing of cash payments can cause variability

Given management's guidance for a "significant increase in CapEx" in 2026E, we raised our FY26E CapEx estimate to $138B, which would represent a 48% increase from the $93B we expect GOOGL will spend in 2025E.

' Now turning to our cash CapEx, which was $34.2 billion in Q3. We've now spent $89.9 billion so far this year. This primarily relates to AWS as we invest to support demand for our AI and core services and in custom silicon, like Trainium, as well as tech infrastructure to support our North America and international segments. We'll continue to make significant investments, especially in AI, as we believe it to be a massive opportunity with the potential for strong returns on invested capital over the long term . Additionally, we continue to invest in our fulfillment and transportation network to support the growth of the business, improve delivery speeds and lower our cost to serve. These investments will support growth for many years to come. Looking ahead, we expect our full year cash CapEx to be approximately $125 billion in 2025, and we expect that amount will increase in 2026 " .

Following management's commentary we raised our FY26E CapEx estimate to $163B, which represents 30% growth from the $125B that AMZN guided to / that we expect they will spend in 2025E. Importantly, we highlight that AMZN has been leading the way on CapEx, and is spending more than any other hyperscaler to support the AI opportunity.

' We currently expect 2025 capital expenditures, including principal payments on finance leases to be in the range of $70 billion to $72 billion, increased from our prior outlook of $66 billion to $72 billion...A central requirement to realizing these opportunities is infrastructure capacity. As we have begun to plan for next year, it's become clear that our compute needs have continued to expand meaningfully, including versus our own expectations last quarter. We are still working through our capacity plans for next year, but we expect to invest aggressively to meet these needs, both by building our own infrastructure and contracting with third-party cloud providers. We anticipate this will provide further upward pressure on our CapEx and expense plans next year. As a result, our current expectation is that CapEx dollar growth will be notably larger in 2026 than 2025" . As a result of management's commentary, we raised our FY26E CapEx estimate to $104B. Google remains a Top Pick for us into 2026 as we believe they are best positioned in advertising as their broader AI leadership story unfold and regulatory overhands fade. We believe fears that search will be displaced by AI driven disintermediation have faded, as GOOGL displays AI product leadership that positions them well to lead the future of AI driven advertising. Importantly, we believe AI Overviews and AI Mode in the Search business are clearly resonating with consumers as adoption builds.

· Google AI Overviews have reached 2 billion monthly users use since launch in 1H24 setting up Search monetization in 2026 and beyond. · Since launch in May, AI Mode has scaled to 100M monthly users in US and India, and is likely to grow with product's roll-out to 200 new countries by end of the year. In addition to the global roll-out, a lift in usage is likely to benefit from the recent integration of agentic features. · Fading pressure from antitrust risk as GOOGL appears positioned for favorable remedy trial outcomes from both the search and ad tech antitrust trials.

U.S. Advertisers are expected to spend $69.3 billion (+18% YoY) on retail media in 2026E. Platforms with retail media networks are likely to benefit from higher lower-funnel ROAS through incremental sales. As these platforms have achieved growing reach and access to unique shopper data, Brand advertisers have also found the medium to be an effective tool for upper-funnel objectives. We believe intent is key for unlocking ROAS for both DR and Brand advertisers on Retail Media. Given this backdrop, Amazon is best positioned following Instacart, Uber, and DoorDash. Exhibit 92 - U.S. Retail Media Spend ($ in B) from 2024A to 2028E Source: BMO Capital Markets, eMarketer

The biggest challenge that Retail Media networks face is attribution across various platforms, which should improve in the next few years as the number of advertisers grows and collects insights. Further, AI should help improve the accuracy of measuring capabilities and speed of classification, that will enable advertisers, agencies, and brands to improve real-time campaign optimization. We believe Amazon and Instacart are best positioned for advertisers' adoption of Retail Media networks. These platforms have the best intent data across the grocery landscape, which should position them well for incremental ad budgets. Uber and DoorDash are also positioned well, given the frequency of use (i.e., daily/monthly usage for 3P Food Delivery versus 1-2x per year for Travel networks).
