We remain highly optimistic regarding CTV monetization over the next five years. For 2026E, we expect enhancements around CTV formats like QR code integrations and shoppable ads have helped transform CTV advertisements from brand spend to performance-driven ad spend, which helps to drive a more clear / measurable ROI for advertisers. As a user can now click a button on an Amazon CTV ad that allows them to add a product to their cart. As such, 2026E should prove to be the inflection year for meaningful CTV monetization as CTV ad spend growth (+18% YoY) continues while linear ad spend as a percentage of total media spend declines by -100bps YoY.

YouTube remains the leader in US engagement, and these trends should continue in 2026. We believe that YouTube is the best platform for Creators to expand their reach and monetize their content given short and long platform videos. As described in our number #4 prediction, YouTube Partner Program combined with new monetization capabilities for Shorts videos, should drive monetization for both on-device and CTV mediums. Netflix is the biggest beneficiary of linear TV dollars set to shift online globally. Given the company's growing AVOD subscribers and steady improvement in programmatic capabilities with The Trade Desk, Amazon DSP, and Google DV 360, we are confident Netflix should onboard a meaningful share of the $20-30 billion of linear TV dollars that likely flows online in the next three years.

We believe this number could prove to be conservative with the potential expansion of the company's ad load. One of our ad experts indicated that Netflix can increase its ad load to 12 minutes without seeing churn. We estimate Netflix's ad load is in the 3-5 minute range, leaving ample room for revenue growth. Linear TV Advertising Dollars Continue to Shift Towards CTV: We highlight that the ~$60B of linear TV ad spend in the U.S. continues to shift towards emerging CTV channel, which is expected to grow 14% YoY in the U.S. in 2026E to $37B. We believe we are still in the early-to-mid innings of this transition, as consumers (and advertisers) increasingly focus their TV efforts around streaming/CTV. NFLX remains the best positioned vendor to capitalize on this trend with their massive subscriber base and 190M Monthly Active Viewers (MAV).

The continued shift of sports streaming rights from linear TV to streamers are a core driver of rising CTV ad spend, as advertisers flock to ramping advertising businesses on CTV as a result of highly attractive sports rights. We highlight that sports content drives premium CPMs from advertisers while also exposing advertisers to the CTV ad opportunity and helps onboard these advertisers to the rest of their inventory. For perspective, premium sports-oriented inventory can demand $40 CPMs, which is above the premium SVOD inventory (such as Stranger Things) that typically demands $30 CPMs, and well above the FAST channels, which usually demand closer to $15 CPMs. Due to the increasing demand for live sports content on CTV, we anticipate that the blended CTV CPM will continue to rise over time. Source: BMO Capital Markets

Programmatic capabilities will underscore significant monetization improvement thanks to Trade Desk, Amazon DSPs, Microsoft, and Google DV360. NFLX's in-house tech was launched in Canada (4Q24), and its capabilities will continue to expand globally in 2026E with launch in 12 markets including the U.K., Germany and Japan. Recently announced NFLX/AMZN partnerships allows advertisers purchasing ads through Amazon to access NFLX's premium ad inventory. For NFLX, the partnership brings more programmatic ad buyers onto its ramping ad business, helping to close the monetization gap with SVOD. Encouragingly, management also highlighted that they are seeing faster growth in programmatic advertising, which they expect will become an increasing part of the incremental revenue contribution in the future.

Source: BMO Capital Markets, Nielsen Gauge

Amazon remains our Top Pick across our eCommerce coverage given its leadership position in SameDay/Next-Day delivery as well as expanding selection of 1P/3P products. Speed (time from checkout to delivery) remains high in importance to consumers and continues to impact conversion rates for sellers across categories. Against that, Amazon continues executing successfully against its regionalization strategy, which began in 2023, to focus on inbound placement of products and expedite delivery speed across its regional network for both Amazon.com and off-platform purchases.

That said, recent economic headwinds are changing consumer shopping patterns and value/affordability is gaining higher importance for consumers. In response to a softening macro backdrop, we see all income groups adopting a value-first playbook - making more frequent trips with smaller baskets and embracing private label brands, with retailers like Walmart seeing grocery private brand penetration rise 60 basis points year-over-year. Lower- and middle-income households are aggressively cutting discretionary spending and relying heavily on discounters and extreme value programs, while highincome consumers maintain premium purchases but increasingly shop through value-focused retailers. Consumer spending is shifting toward essentials, with retail food and beverage dollars rising while discretionary general merchandise declining, and grocers reporting significant trade-down within categories.

As high prices remain a major concern for consumers and inflation pressure, moderating but still elevated, seems unlikely to dissipate any time soon, we expect consumers to become extremely valueoriented in 2026. As a result, retailers offering competitive pricing should see an opportunity to gain share of wallet. Against such a backdrop, we expect Amazon to fare quite well given its price advantage, sustained for nine years in a row, on top of its leadership in expedited delivery and product selection. According to the latest annual Price Wars study by Profitero+, Amazon remains the ultimate leader in all 16 categories (covering over 10,000 items) across 23 leading retailers. The study, conducted in July through September 2025, shows that Amazon maintained its pricing lead in 2025, with an average price advantage of 14% over competitors , on par with 14% advantage in 2024. Other key takeaways from the Profitero+ study include:

· Amazon increased its price advantage in Toys & Games from 10% to 13% · Walmart narrowed its price gap from 5% to 4% ○ With improvements across 10 of the 16 categories analyzed - most notably in Video Games, where the gap shrank from 12% to just 3% · Target maintained last year's improvement, holding steady at prices 13% higher than Amazon's · Wayfair narrowed its price gap from 17% to 11% We expect Amazon's competitive pricing to provide a critical competitive advantage in a macro environment with elevated inflation expectations and softening labor market.

As of late 2025, Amazon has significantly expanded its logistics capabilities, transforming its set of supply chain services into a comprehensive utility (called Supply Chain by Amazon) for third-party merchants. It offers a fully-automated suite of end-to-end supply chain services that allow merchants to get their products from manufacturers to customers around the world, with Amazon picking up inventory from their suppliers' manufacturing facilities, shipping it across borders, handling customs clearance and ground transportation, storing inventory in bulk, managing replenishment across Amazon and other sales channels, and delivering directly to customers. Exhibit 98 - How Supply Chain by Amazon Works Source: Amazon

A part of that set, Amazon Warehousing and Distribution (AWD) has evolved into a global service (GWD - Global Warehousing and Distribution), enabling upstream bulk storage near manufacturing hubs. Simultaneously, Multi-Channel Fulfillment (MCF) has broadened Amazon's reach to support major external platforms, including Walmart, Shopify, eBay, and SHEIN, positioning the company's logistics network as a back-end solution for the broader eCommerce ecosystem.

With off-platform purchases becoming an important element of Amazon's retail business (discussed here ), AWD/GWD and MCF unlock significant opportunities for sellers to increase conversion and drive sales growth. The company is seeing tangible gains, with merchants using MCF for off-Amazon channels reporting a 19% average increase in sales along with a 19% reduction in out-of-stock rates and a 12% improvement in inventory turnover (as of Sep '25). MCF is available in the U.S., Canada, Mexico, five European countries, Japan, India, and Australia. Amazon has reported that its logistics services support over 600,000 sellers worldwide who move over 5 billion items annually through its network. Exhibit 99 - Amazon Multi-Channel Fulfilment Flow Source: Amazon

During Amazon's 3Q25 earnings call, management mentioned that the company's regionalized network is operating at scale, but they continue to fine-tune and improve fulfillment operations. As a result, U.S. inbound lead time has declined by nearly four days compared to 2024, with a positive impact on working capital. In addition, by placing inventory more strategically throughout the network, Amazon can offer U.S. customers the ability to order perishable groceries and receive them the same day in as little as five hours. The company is seeing positive early results since launching in January, with customers visiting the site more often and returning twice as often as non-perishable shoppers. Amazon plans to continue investing in smaller Same-Day buildings in the coming years. These buildings require lower incremental CapEx than the large-scale fulfillment centers built during the pandemic. As a result, delivery speed should increase, which will improve customer experience levels and, combined, create a positive multi-year FCF unlock on the retail business.

Social commerce allows shoppers to discover and purchase products directly on their social media feeds. It gained rapid traction in China, given early investments by Alibaba and JD.com, reinforced by consumer behavior that skews more mobile than in other regions. While the U.S. has been somewhat slow to adopt these shopping trends, social commerce continues to gain share relative to overall eCommerce sales in the country. Social commerce adoption is expected to continue over the next several years, as the average user interacts with around 6.8 platforms monthly and roughly 58% of U.S. shoppers have purchased a product they saw on social media, according to industry estimates. Specifically, MCF on TikTok has improved peak orders for certain sellers by 15x, given its attractive click-to-delivery speed and better than 97% on-time delivery rates.

That said, industry estimates for 2026E and beyond have barely budged over the past year, given ongoing macro uncertainty and persistent pricing pressure across practically all verticals. Further, social commerce adoption in the U.S. remains well below APAC, mainly owing to consumer shopping preferences, which favor delivery speed in the U.S. That said, Amazon fulfillment should help unlock social commerce demand as consumers are provided with greater selection and faster delivery speeds relative to the current offering. Exhibit 100 - U.S. Social Commerce Sales ($B) Source: BMO Capital Markets, eMarketer Exhibit 101 - U.S. and China Social Commerce Penetration Source: BMO Capital Markets, eMarketer

The Home Furnishings category, cyclical and closely tied to the housing market, is also quite big estimated at roughly $500 billion in Wayfair's four markets: the U.S., Canada, the U.K., and Ireland. And although the cyclical trough would be hard to pinpoint, management is already seeing signs of industry's negative growth turning flattish in 2025. Recall that in 2021, consumers were flush with cash and quarantined at home, which resulted in a step function increase in home remodeling - both large and small projects. As a result, the post-pandemic decline had lasted for over two years and just now management is seeing some sustainable improvement. This uptrend, however, is overlapping with an economy that feels rather uncertain and showing signs of softening. Ultimately, it's hard to predict which way consumer spend on furnishings would go, but we continue to view Wayfair as the industry leader, positioned well to gain market share in any macro

environment. We also like the fact that Wayfair has made progress in 2025 on providing better value to consumers, as reflected in Profitero+'s Price Wars study (6 pts improvement from 2024). That said, CastleGate continues to prove effective, reaching 97% of U.S. consumers in under two days and removing purchase friction between Wayfair's over 20,000 suppliers and 22 million buyers. Further, about 20% of the company's employees are technologists, extending Wayfair's leadership position as online penetration in Home Furnishings continues to grow relative to overall spending. AI and machine learning are at the center of the Wayfair platform. The R&D teams continue to be led by Co-Founder Steven Conine. The R&D teams have built a highly complex and impressive technology stack that includes image quality models, product matching capabilities, programmatic bids across digital ad formats to maximize ROAS, and its end-to-end shipping solution for suppliers and customers.

With 200,000 new products added to Wayfair each quarter, the likelihood that the right product is served to the right shopper increases with the proliferation of AI. Exhibit 102 - Wayfair's Predicted Winners Machine Learning Models Source: BMO Capital Markets, Wayfair

With respect to tariffs, management has shared that there wasn't a significant pull forward of demand, except for a couple of pockets of time. And the pull forward had been in very specific categories and just measured in days. On the balance, tariffs have had a minimal effect so far and management does not think tariffs have driven consumer behavior into pulled-forward purchases. As for the impact from raised tariffs on product pricing, management has shared that a lot of the tariffrelated cost increases had been absorbed by suppliers, willing to take lower margins on their existing product lines or offset by transportation cost buffers built into quoted prices. However, management expects new product lines to get introduced at higher price points (adjusted to offset higher tariffs) introducing more inflation down the road.

From a macro perspective, the most important factors for the Home Furnishings category remain the health of the housing market, the overall health of the economy, consumers' wage situation, and consumer sentiment. Unfortunately, only one of these four factors looks encouraging today - growth in real wages - but only for those that already have a job. We expect Wayfair to continue gaining wallet share in the category given the large and growing addressable market opportunity. With an annual customer spend of roughly $550 on Wayfair, the share of wallet opportunity remains significant, given average household spend on the category at around $3,000. Category sales in 2025 are notably well above pre-pandemic levels and average growth through September (the latest reported month due to the government shutdown) is notably above YoY growth in 2023 and 2024. We don't have visibility into the holiday shopping period, but we also don't expect material divergence from trends earlier in the year. Exhibit 103 - U.S. Furniture and Home Furnishings Retail Sales ($M) 14,000

Source: BMO Capital Markets, U.S. Census Bureau

Focus category growth has been accelerating five quarters in a row and has helped eBay get really close to achieving its goal of mid-single-digit Marketplace GMV growth for the year. Over time, eBay expects roughly 50% of GMV will come from its focus categories, up from about 25% at the end of 2022. Parts & Accessories (P&A) remains the largest focus category, with over 750 million live listings, and the second-largest contributor to growth in 3Q25. Collectibles, for second quarter in a row, contributed the most to growth in the quarter, driven by accelerating growth in trading cards. Fashion (including luxury, streetwear and apparel) remains another major contributor, followed by all other focus categories. We think eBay's targeted full-funnel marketing approach, focused on enthusiasts in focus categories, has been paying off with improved return on ad spend. 25% Exhibit 104 - Focus Categories vs. Marketplace GMV Growth Source: BMO Capital Markets, eBay

As consumers adjust purchase behavior in response to softening macro and stagnated labor market, we expect to see increasing traffic to eBay's platform and corresponding growth of GMV, given eBay's strong value proposition. And with middle- and high-income consumers trading down too, we expect to see incremental tailwinds to most of eBay's major categories including Fashion, Handbags, Watches, Refurbished Electronics, and Parts & Accessories.

Parts & Accessories is eBay's largest focus category (750 million live listings and GMV in excess of $10 billion), with durable growth in the MSD range. The company continues introducing features to enhance the customer experience, including the critical Guaranteed Fit, which guarantees auto parts will correctly fit or shopper gets their money back . We note that this program was launched in the UK and Germany in September 2023, following its successful roll-out in the U.S. seven months earlier. The program leverages over 5 billion pieces of incremental fitment data to ensure consumers get the right part they need, thus establishing critical trust in the category, along with free and easy returns (flexible 30-day return window, free shipping labels, accelerated refund processing). Not surprisingly, eBay has reported double-digit increase in conversions on these listings.

Collectibles is another eBay category in excess of $10 billion with appealing growth outlook and a full-funnel business across all price points, following the relatively recent acquisitions of TCGplayer and Goldin. The former is a low- to mid-ASP collectible-cards business that effectively connects enthusiasts with like-minded communities and improves the overall online experience for the category. In May 2024, eBay acquired Goldin, which auctions high-value trading cards and collectibles, and has been integrating its inventory directly into the eBay marketplace to enhance the overall value for enthusiasts. Authentication is a key component of focus category growth as it significantly improves crosssell opportunities on the platform. This includes investments in vehicle compatibility for P&A, luxury authentication, and 20-day free returns.

eBay is one of the biggest beneficiaries of AI The company has invested in AI for many years across the business to improve both buyer and seller experience. eBay has achieved significant AI adoption with over 10 million sellers using AI tools to create over 300 million listings at a rate of roughly 500,000 new AI-generated listings per day, fundamentally transforming the listing creation process. In 2024, the company upgraded its Gen AI capabilities by increasing its GPU capacity, deploying its first supercomputer, improving hardware utilization, and developing architectures optimized for LLMs. The enhanced AI platform enabled eBay to build and run models approximately 100 times larger than the prior year. We believe eBay is well-positioned to benefit further from its Gen AI tools and products.

With high prices a key concern for consumers, we believe that value would trump selection and speed in 2026, but the latter two remain important. Nevertheless, Amazon maintains a competitive advantage across all three of these dimensions and remains our top pick in eCommerce.

We like Amazon because of its leading position in AI/Cloud, retail media/advertising, and retail in the U.S. and globally . AWS is the market share leader with roughly 50% of public cloud spend and is best positioned to benefit from the exploding demand for Cloud capacity for AI workloads. We believe AWS is among the leaders in the foundational and middle layers of the Gen AI/ML stack. With the proliferation of Gen AI workloads, AWS growth accelerated in 3Q25 and we model further acceleration through 1H26E. Advertising is now a $70B+ run-rate business which further supports Amazon's flywheel, with upside to estimates given secular and idiosyncratic tailwinds. We believe the ongoing roll-out of expedited delivery infrastructure with lower CapEx vs. fulfillment centers is both improving the customer experience and unlocking Retail FCF in 2026 and onward.

We also like eBay given 1) the acceleration in focus categories, 2) adoption of BNPL driving higher AOV carts and younger customers, 3) solid and improving profitability, 4) ad revenue acceleration, 5) Active Buyer base returning to platform, and 6) easing competitive pressure from Temu/Shein. We are keeping an eye on ongoing tariff and macro uncertainties and lapping substantial trading card growth in 4Q25. Our view is that Wayfair remains well-positioned longer term, but we await more near-term signals that indicate the Home Furnishings category is on firmer footing . We like that management is executing well, delivering strong financial performance and KPIs. We expect improvements in price and selection to drive top-line growth in 2026E while lapping restructuring efforts should support margin expansion. We also like ongoing investments to capture share of $500 billion TAM. Still, cyclical headwinds outweigh attractive secular growth for now, and we remain on the sidelines.

Industry Growth Remains Subdued Following COVID-19 Driven Boost Following strong growth in the video game industry from: 1) The rise of the Battle Royale genre; 2) COVID-19 driven growth (2020-2021), the industry has returned to a low-single-digit growth outlook as investors question what the next major catalyst to the gaming space will be. According to NewZoo, the video game industry is set to grow at a 3.1% 4-Year CAGR ('24-28E), representing a bleak outlook for industry growth and underscoring the maturity of the industry following decades of meaningful growth stages like the rise of digital downloads, microstransactions, Battle Royale, and COVID-19 (among others).

While Industry Growth is Slow, The Largest Publishers Continue to Gain Share While NewZoo estimates suggest that the video game industry will only grow at a 3.1% CAGR (2024-2028E), we highlight that the largest video game companies are set to grow meaningfully faster as the biggest franchises continue to gain share. For perspective, consensus estimates imply that TTWO, RBLX and EA grow at a 3-year CAGR of 13%, 21% and 5% respectively, underscoring how the largest publishers are positioned to gain share against a gaming ecosystem only growing at a 3.1% CAGR. Additionally, we believe the generational-event launch of GTA VI could possibly serve as a positive catalyst to the entire gaming ecosystem (over time) by driving a meaningful improvement in the installation base, which ultimately allows all publishers to sell more games to consumers. We also believe GTA VI is likely to include some transformational gameplay that could support faster industry growth.

Source: Newzoo, BMO Capital Markets

Console to gain share of gaming ecosystem at expense of mobile Source: Newzoo, BMO Capital Markets

|                    | 2026E   | 2027E   | 2028E   | 3-YearCAGR   |
|--------------------|---------|---------|---------|--------------|
| TTWO               | 8%      | 32%     | 1%      | 13%          |
| RBLX               | 22%     | 21%     | 20%     | 21%          |
| EA                 | 7%      | 4%      | 5%      | 5%           |
| Video GameIndustry | 3%      | 3%      | 3%      | 3%           |

We see the rise of UGC as the next core catalyst to the video game space, as developers look to adopt user-generated-content that helps to shift the risk of game development onto individual developers, allowing game developers to benefit from the upside, while removing the risk of creating games that fail to resonate with consumers. We note that the rise of UGC corresponds at a similar time in the gaming industry in which the biggest companies have meaningfully pulled back on investments behind new intellectual property, as the risks of creating a game that fail to resonate with consumers continues to grow.

While UGC has been around for decades (think custom game modes in Halo and other large AAA games), we highlight that Roblox has helped to put the financial opportunity of UGC on the radar of every game development company. Roblox operates a platform of games that are completely user generated, as RBLX's core job is to invest and build tools that allow users to develop their own games on the platform. As a result, RBLX has scaled a massive platform where over 5M developers on the platform earn some kind of revenue, and 150M+ DAUs flock to the platform on a daily basis to gain access to millions of free games. Exhibit 108 - Breakdown of Roblox Developer and Creator Rewards in 2023 Source: Roblox While Roblox has an early lead in the UGC opportunity, we highlight that competition is ramping quickly, and we expect large publishers like EA and TTWO are likely to go after the opportunity following the explosive growth that they have observed by RBLX.

We have been writing about the meaningful push that Epic Games has been making in UGC, using their existing Fortnite platform as a key driver of their UGC ambitions. Specifically, Epic Games / Fortnite has made 2 specific announce: · Announced meaningful increases in UGC creator revenue share for 2026 · Partnered with Unity to bring games created on Unity into the Fortnite UGC ecosystem While competition in the UGC space is increasing, we believe the addressable market opportunity is massive, and that there is room for multiple winners who in turn can use the opportunity to drive faster revenue growth for the broader gaming industry. Importantly, the proliferation of UGC could help to improve the broader margin structure of public video game companies by eliminating the hit / bust risk of new game development and offloading that risk to smaller individual user / private UGC game platforms, allowing AAA game publisher to benefit from the hit games without taking the risk on new IP development.

Anticipate continued consolidation in the video game space. While we expect consolidation will be a broader trend among the tech space, we believe the video game industry is likely ripe for continued consolidation and acquisitions. We remind investors of MSFT's massive $69B acquisition of Activision announced in 2022. Following that acquisition, there was not a ton of transactions in the gaming space, until a consortium of investors made the largest ever leveraged-buyout (LBO) of EA for $55B. Following this transaction, we believe more assets in the space are likely to consolidate, and believe that TTWO could be a target for strategic players peripherally in the space like AMZN, GOOGL and NFLX, who are large companies that can absorb a transaction of that size who have shown intense interest to be in the video game space. We believe RBLX could be a potential roll-up story, as they continue to build out their capabilities to support a UGC game environment at scale.

Expect Industry Growth to Be Driven by Biggest Games Getting Bigger as Investment Into New IP Remains Subdued: We anticipate that much of the low-single-digit growth in the gaming industry will be driven by the largest games in the world, as those games continue to gain share of the ~$190B global video game market. Notably, we believe publishers will continue to shy away from development of new IP, which presents meaningful risk to publishers if said new IP fails to resonate with consumers upon launching.

giving them a larger install base to sell into. A key component to understanding video game sales is understanding the console cycle. Consoles go through multi-year cycles in which the core hardware developers (Sony and Microsft) release a new generation of hardware every 5-7 years. We highlight that as it gets later in the console cycle, publishers tend to benefit from a larger install base of gamer on the latest iteration of hardware. For example, the current hardware cycle began in 2020, in which 8M units of net-gen hardware solid, which had headwinds from mid-year launch and COVID-19 driven supply chain disruptions. Notably, that install base has grown by 20M+ annually, and we expect to end 2025 with ~130M consoles in the install base.

We expect that the upcoming mega launch of GTA VI in November 2026 will serve as a positive catalyst to the broader video game industry by helping to accelerate console sales as consumers look to purchase the newest hardware to play the biggest video game launch of all time. Notably, we expect this to be supported by the game reactivating prior gamers who have left the ecosystem but have been awaiting to return on the GTA VI launch.

Source: BMO Capital Markets, Circana Jumping From One Platform to the Next: Cross-Platform, Device Play, & Revisiting Handheld Consoles New Portable / on-the-go Consoles Could Support Growth: On-the-go gaming devices are seeing improved capabilities with each generation, and increased focus and investment by players like Nintendo, Xbox, Sony and Valve could help drive continued improvements and growth in portable gaming. Lines are blurring between mobile, console, and PC gaming as cross-platform gameplay and handheld have taken off due to technological advances in the industry. Cross-platform play allows players to log into their gaming accounts on every device and play and socialize with friends regardless of their chosen device.

The launch of iPhone Pro 15 allowed users to play *some* AAA console games on their mobile devices. This impressive technological feat continues to advance as players have commented that the launch of the iPhone 16 Pro has even better frame rates than the iPhone 15. While the experience and tech fall below that of a console, we think this represents the start of a potential step up in growth for the industry from user expansion. These trends are hugely beneficial for the biggest AAA game franchises. Globally, gamers have a voracious appetite for the biggest AAA gaming brands, even if they offer a different experience from the core game. This also supports our thesis that big publishers will continue to gain more market shares given the network effect and ability to invest more in technology for cross-platform gaming. Of our covered names, EA's various sports franchises and RBLX have found success by embracing new business models (ads, subscription, free-to-play) and platforms (mobile and PC).

· Four EA Sports FC games are under the franchise umbrella: EA Sports FC, EA Sports FC Online, EA Sports FC Ultimate Team, and EA Sports FC Mobile, which will bring the EA Sports brand to a massmarket, global audience. · RBLX allows users to play and interact across multiple platforms. The game initially launched on PC (2006) and moved into cross-platform gaming, with mobile launches with iOS (2006) and Android (2014), and then console Xbox (2015) and PS4 (2023). The cross-platform/cross-device play line has become increasingly blurred as both MSFT's Xbox and SONY have launched their own handheld console devices this year - which was one of our predictions for 2025. Both handhelds do not have true cross-platform play capabilities but the ROG XBox Ally has some crossplatform features on select games.

· Xbox has partnered with ASUS ROG to create the ROG Xbox Ally and ROG Xbox Ally X, which are handheld gaming devices that offer a full Xbox experience on a Windows 11 operating system. The devices provide access to Xbox Game Pass and PC games, with features like automatic save syncing across devices. · Sony has released several handheld gaming devices, including the PocketStation, various PlayStation Portable (PSP) models, the PlayStation Vita, and most recently, the PlayStation Portal. The PlayStation Portal is a handheld streaming device that allows users to play PS5 games over Wi-Fi, and with recent updates, can also function as a standalone cloud streaming device with a PlayStation Plus Premium subscription. There is also speculation regarding a new, more powerful Sony handheld, code named "Project Canis," potentially launching around 2027.

With the launch of the aforementioned handhelds, both companies would be competing against Nintendo's Switch which has sold 152.3M units since launch in 2017 more than the 84.2M for PS5 and 33.7M for the Series X and S. Both MSFT and Sony handhelds are in the early stages but are getting to closer to cross-platform capabilities. Sony's ambition is to have its handheld device play PS5 games without an active WiFi connection, and we think it is reasonable to assume that Microsoft has plans for similar gaming capabilities. Both console companies have noted that the products remain a few years out, and we expect the devices in 2027E with the expected new console launch. Given the potential disruption, we will be monitoring the updates around this in 2026 closely.

We remain bullish and expect this to drive significant growth across the industry given that 1) handheld devices require less equipment than a console (no TV needed), 2) will likely become more affordable and expand reach, and 3) increase time spent gaming as players will be able to play anywhere. Exhibit 111 - Current Console Generation Unit Sales (M) as of 3Q25 Source: BMO Capital Markets, Sony, Nintendo, VGChartz

TTWO (Top-Pick) is the best-positioned publisher with the Mega-Launch of GTA VI in November 2026E. TTWO remains our top pick in the video game space (again) into 2026, as we see the launch of GTA VI on November 19, 2026 as possibly the biggest event in video game history. For background, the lunch of GTA VI has now been delayed multiple times, previously planning to release in Fall 2025, the game was later delayed to May 26, 2026. However, in November, TTWO announced that they would delay the game by another 6 months, with a new release date of November 19, 2026. We believe GTA VI is likely to release on its current launch date, as the Rockstar team has now had another year of development, which we believe helps to underscore the massive transformational gaming experience that the team is building, that will underscore the next decade of growth for TTWO. We have written extensively about our expectations for GTA VI, including our GTA VI deep dive where we highlighted our assumption that the game will sell 45M units in its launch window.

Though Outside of GTA VI, TTWO has an Attractive Pipeline: While TTWO's pipeline is headlined by the mega-launch of GTA VI, we highlight that their broader pipeline remains highly attractive, including the Launch of Judas. Project ETHOS and the next iteration in the BioShock franchise. We believe TTWO's attractive pipeline of mostly owned IP positions them well to drive value for shareholders. GTA VI Delay Driven Sell-Offs Create a Buying Opportunity: As we have stated previously, we strongly view any sell-offs in TTWO's stock from announcements that GTA VI is delayed as meaningful opportunities to buy the stock. Ultimately, we believe game delays have minimal to no impact on the underlying success of a game, and highlight only minimal impacts to our DCF. As a result, we continue to encourage investors to purchase TTWO's stock if it declines from GTA VI delays. However, we anticipate that GTA VI will now lunch on its currently launch date of 11/19/26. Exhibit 113 - TTWO Stock Chart with GTA VI Delays Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports

GTA VI will launch and sell 45M units in its launch window in 2026/2027, ultimately becoming the highest-grossing video game title of all time. On 12/5/24, we published our GTA VI deep dive report, outlining our expectations for GTA VI while looking back at prior iterations of GTA V as a guidepost. In our analysis, we assume that GTA VI will sell 45M units in its launch window, which implies that ~30% of the ~150M current gen consoles purchase the game in the launch window. BMO's Proprietary Video Game Survey Supports GTA VI as the Most Anticipated Game: We ran a proprietary survey on June 16, 2025 to 750 U.S. consumers who play video games to gauge their purchase intent in the gaming space. The results of the survey were most positive for TTWO, as respondents were overwhelmingly positive on their purchase intent for GTA VI. Encourangly, given a list of the biggest upcoming games, 36% of consumers called GTA VI the release that they were most excited about, and 92% of consumers said they were likely to purchase GTA VI, above the 91% who reported having purchased a GTA game in their lifetime.

RBLX was one of the best-performing names in our coverage universe in 2025, with shares up 63% YTD (as of 12/10/25) supported by a step function change in platform engagement. We believe key unlocks around search and discovery were the primary driver, which led to multiple new games on the platform scaling in ways never seen before on Roblox, or gaming, as multiple Roblox games ( Grow a Garden and Steal a Brainrot) broke all time video game current user records (which were previously held by Fortnite). Earlier in 2025, RBLX would see peak concurrent users of ~10M in any given week; however, these unlocks helped to drive an all-time high of 42.6M concurrent users on the platform, which has maintained in the mid-low-30M concurrent user range since.

However, we highlight that peak concurrent users have begun to fade following a multi-quarter period of meaningfully ramping engagement. Specifically, we note that the weekly peak concurrent user count (typically Saturdays) has declined WoW for 8 straight weeks, falling from 37.0M to 29.7M in the most recent week. We are closely monitoring to see when RBLX peak CCUs may find a floor to build off of again, but we remain confident that RBLX will return to setting engagement records again in the future. Exhibit 120 - Peak Concurrent RBLX Users (in M) Source: Romonitorstats, BMO Capital Markets

The Biggest Games on The Platform are Changing: Grow a Garden was the original breakout hit game on RBLX, which reached 474M visits on a single day in August. While Grow a Garden was the initial spark that set the platform on fire, we highlight the game has become a fraction of what it was previously, and currently only generated ~20M visits per day, which is down meaningful from its peak of 474M. However, as Grow a Garden visitation has faltered, other games like Steal a Brainrot and 99 Nights in The Forest have taken its place, helping to support continued strength in the platform. Importantly, we believe the recent increase in engagement is driven by key unlocks around broader search and discovery on Roblox rather than the creation of any specific hit games. Because of this dynamic, we expect many more games will take the platform by storm in the coming years. Exhibit 121 - Daily Visits (in M) To Grow a Garden Source: Romonitorstats, BMO Capital Markets

Exhibit 123 - Daily Visits (in M) To 99 Nights in The Forest Source: Romonitorstats, BMO Capital Markets Exhibit 122 - Daily Visits (in M) To Steal a Brainrot Source: Romonitorstats, BMO Capital Markets Exhibit 124 - Daily Visits (in M) To Plants vs Brainrot Source: Romonitorstats, BMO Capital Markets

· How durable is the recent engagement bump? · How will age verification initiatives and ensuing player segmentation impact player engagement? · How impactful will ramping competition from competitors (like Fortnite) be to RBLX's growth? · How quickly can RBLX ramp a meaningful advertising business?

Advertising is Immaterial Today, But we Think it Could be a Meaningful Business Over Time: While RBLX's advertising business remains an insignificant business today, we highlight the business is still early in its ramp. Importantly, we highlight that RBLX's MASSIVE user base of 152M DAUs provides the meaningful building blocks to support a scaled ad business over time. For perspective, while RBLX's 152M DAUS is dwarfed by SNAP's 477M, it is also meaningfully larger than RDDT's 116M DAUs. Importantly, RBLX's DAUs are growing fast, and the age up thesis makes the vast majority of users on the platform addressable to the advertising opportunity. Importantly for RBLX vs RDDT/SNAP, advertising would be an ancillary business to RBLX, rather than a core driver of the fundamental story, making it an attractive "call-option" on the broader gaming opportunity. We also believe RBLX's ability to use advertising to drive rewards for users creates an intriguing value prop vs

other platforms. Exhibit 125 - DAUs by Platform Source: BMO Capital Markets, Company Reports

With 78% of Roblox players indicating that they would purchase a real world item that was advertised to them on Roblox. We believe this helps to underscore the value that Roblox could provide to advertisers, as leaned in daily active users at scale indicate that ads on the platform could actually impact their purchasing decisions.

We believe this will serve as a meaningful advantage as RBLX looks to build out an ad business, which we believe can scale with both video and display advertising. EA Acquisition to Close in 2026E Following the $55B leveraged buyout of EA by a consortium of investors including Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF), Silverlake and Affinity Partners we expect the transaction will ultimately close in 2Q26E, bringing EA into the private markets. We believe EA enters the private market with strength on the heels of a successful Battlefield 6 launch. However, we question if a leverage buyout, which will saddle the company with a heavy debt service payment, is the optimal way for this asset to grow. We believe the debt burden could possibly limit EA's ability to invest in new franchises.

Ubisoft has Steadied The Boat and is Looking to Get Back on Track in 2026E Following a tough few years for UBI, we believe they have the foundation in place to build off of, largely supported by the closing of a €1.16B investment by Tencent that gives them a 26.32% ownership of Vantage Studios. As a result, UBI will be able to pay down debt and lower its leverage ratio, as they further invest into their largest IP to drive a return to revenue growth following a transition year in calendar 2025.

The rise of prediction markets (Kalshi, Polymarket, etc.) in the U.S. has changed the U.S. sportsbetting landscape and essentially made sportsbetting accessible at a federal level in all 50 states through the introduction of "event contracts" that are regulated by the CFTC. As a result of the rise of prediction markets, DKNG ended up acquiring a CFTC licensed exhange (Railbird) which sets the stage for them to launch their own prediction market in December 2025. However, shortly after this acquisition, a Judge in Nevada removed a prior injunction that will now allow the states to enforce a ban on prediction markets in the state, presenting a major legal win for legal OSB operators and states that collect tax revenue from them. We ultimately believe the legality of prediction markets will eventually come down to a U.S. Supreme Court decision.

· Prediction Market competition · NBA/MLB Betting Scandals · Unfavorable Sports Outcomes · Higher state taxes on iGaming/OSB operations The Fate of Prediction Markets Remains Unclear: While prediction markets have taken the country by storm, we believe the future of prediction markets in the U.S. remain somewhat unclear. In our view, prediction markets are a clear backdoor to sportsbetting, in which users are able to bet on sports through "event contracts" that are regulated at the federal level through the CFTC rather than regulated at the state level like traditional online sports betting. While Kalshi and prediction markets caught some initial courtroom victories, a key ruling from a Judge in Nevada in late November brings into question the legality of sports prediction markets. Ultimately, we suspect the supreme court will make a ruling on legality of prediction markets.

We see DKNG as well-positioned to be a long-term winner in the U.S. OSB/iGaming market. The U.S. Sports betting market is currently dominated by two key players: DKNG and FLUT (Fanduel), who control the vast majority of the U.S. market. Several vendors, including Fanatics, ESPN Bet, Bet MGM, etc., are fighting for market share. We see DKNG as well-positioned, given its best-in-class technology, early mover advantage, and brand recognition, which we expect will help DKNG to retain a meaningful share in the industry. We highlight that the TAM in North America alone is significant, and is expected to grow to $63B in 2030 (per Flutter) with a $39B OSB TAM, and a $24B iGaming TAM.

Source: Flutter, BMO Capital Markets

Source: Visible Alpha, BMO Capital Markets Accelerated State OSB Legalization Will Come: We strongly anticipate that states will increasingly look to legalize OSB in 2026E/2027E as the rise of prediction markets leads states to legalize, regulate and tax state gaming partners like DKNG and FLUT (Not covered). Since prediction markets are regulated at the federal level, they avoid paying taxes to states for gaming related revenues like traditional OSB operators do. As a result, as prediction markets essentially provide a backdoor to online sports betting, we believe states will look to legalize OSB so that the states can generate tax revenue from the sports betting activity that is already going on in their state through prediction markets.

Key states remain offline, including Texas and California. We highlight that the legalization and launch of sportsbetting in Missouri on 12/1/25 made it the 29th state in which DKNG had OSB operations. However, while the majority of states have now legalized, we highlight that large states like Texas, California and Florida remain inaccessible to key operators like DraftKings and FanDuel. While these large states remain offline, we highlight that OSB is legal in Florida, but the Seminole tribe has an essential monopoly until 2051 through a legal ruling. Additionally, we suspect that California's eventual legalization is likely to place the economic opportunity within the local tribe's power. This leaves Texas as a key state for investors to monitor from an OSB legalization front over the coming years, though we highlight there are still roadblocks to legalization in Texas.

iGaming is Still in its Infancy. While OSB has been legalized in over half of the 50 U.S. states, we highlight that iGaming (traditional luck based casino games) has only been legalized in 7 states. We believe much of the opportunity in legalization remains in iGaming, with large states like NY, who has legal OSB, still offline from an iGaming perspective. Exhibit 130 - Gaming Still Remains Early in Its Shift to Online as Land Based Gaming Has ~70% Share U.S. QUARTERLY REVENUE BY VERTICAL AND ONLINE SHARE 2021-2025 Source: American Gaming Association Exhibit 131 - iGaming Opportunity Remains Early, Only Legal in Seven States Source: American Gaming Association

support. We highlight that the sports betting / iGaming operators (DKNG/FLUT) are still early in their ramp as meaningful FCF stories. We believe DKNG is set to meaningfully grow its FCF and FCF margin over the next few years, however, rising state taxes and prediction market threats present key risks to this thesis. However, we believe if DKNG is able to operate through these headwinds, that the FCF ramp will provide meaningful valuation support as investors are able to back up the truck on attractive FCF yields. Indications That Tech Is Steadily Unlocking $1.7T Online Grocery TAM 3P food delivery growth continues at a low-teens annual rate as expanding supply optionality produces incremental frequency among existing users while new user growth remains attractive. Further, couriers/drivers continue to seek incremental income given the inflationary environment, which improves overall ETA for consumers and limits the potential for cost deleverage in 2026E. We are seeing continued progress among online delivery platforms to increase the cost-effective adoption of online grocery. Notably, 1) platforms have reduced the cost to serve groceries, 2) selection continues to expand, and 3) the user experience is improving. According to industry estimates, grocery sales in the U.S. will be just under $1.7 trillion in 2026E, with digital representing just 14% and rising to 16% by 2029E. We believe recent supply and demand initiatives could accelerate online adoption in the coming years.

Exhibit 134 - U.S. Online Grocery TAM ($B) and Percentage of Total Source: BMO Capital Markets, eMarketer

· In early 2025, Amazon introduced a pilot, offering perishable groceries to Prime members in certain markets for Same-Day Delivery. By mid-August, the company had scaled the service to Prime members across over 1,000 U.S. cities, and by mid-December it expanded to over 2,300 cities and towns, with plans for additional expansion in 2026. · Amazon's grocery integration is driving strong customer interest, with 70% of perishables customers being first-time Amazon grocery shoppers and those purchasing fresh items returning to shop twice as often as non-perishables customers. · In early December 2025, Amazon also started a pilot for ultra-fast 30-minute Delivery service in select areas of Seattle and Philadelphia. The new service, branded Amazon Now, is integrated into the existing Amazon shopping app and website for customers in eligible ZIP codes. Customers can choose from thousands of household essentials and fresh grocery items, including milk, produce, electronics, and over-the-counter medicines.

· In October 2025, Instacart partnered with Grubhub to offer grocery delivery services across the U.S. to customers on Grubhub and Seamless. Later, in November, Instacart announced a partnership with Airbnb (starting in January 2026) to allow guests to order groceries on Instacart through the Airbnb app and website during their Airbnb stay in select cities. Also in November, the company introduced AI Solutions - a suite of AI tools for grocers including Agentic Commerce and Cart Assistant, with launch partners including Kroger and Sprouts Farmers Market.

· In early December 2025, Instacart launched a shopping app on ChatGPT becoming the first grocery partner to offer embedded, end-to-end shopping and Instant Checkout. The new integration makes it easier than ever for people to go from meal inspiration to doorstep delivery, using Instacart's real-time grocery network and fulfillment capabilities with the help of OpenAI frontier model capabilities. · In July 2025, Instacart launched a pilot for its AI-powered smart carts called Caper Carts with Wegmans, and later in September expanded their omnichannel capabilities with loyalty and SNAP-EBT integrations along with improved product recommendations. · Uber Eats achieved a $12 billion Gross Bookings run rate for Grocery & Retail (G&R) in 3Q25, with 7% of Delivery first-time users acquired through G&R while existing users increasing frequency by 27% after G&R.

· In 2025, Uber expanded its relationship with Kroger (adding more than 2,600 stores across all Kroger banners) and signed many new merchants to the platform, including FreshDirect, ALDI (with over 2,500 stores nationwide and the platform's first retailer to accept SNAP-EBT nationwide), Dollar General, Family Dollar, and Dollar Tree. · DoorDash deepened its Kroger partnership in 2025, fulfilling roughly 1 million orders in the first month through Kroger's new hybrid model that leans on store-based fulfillment and expanded relationships with DoorDash. · The company also launched DashMart Fulfillment Services (DFS), to manage retailers' inventory, picking, packing, and last-mile via DashMarts; early adopters included CVS Pharmacy and Party City, with Kroger 'coming soon.'

· All major platforms advanced autonomous delivery capabilities in 2025, with Uber partnering with Starship for over 2,700 robots, expanding to over 12,000 by 2027, and DoorDash testing with Waymo, while expanding Coco Robotics to Miami.

We continue to favor Uber in the 3P delivery space given 1) its leadership position in Mobility and Delivery, which offers effective cross-sell opportunities; 2) its scale, which ensures Uber will remain the first call for autonomous vehicle OEMs looking to monetize their significant CapEx spend; 3) industry tailwinds, as consumers continue to become habituated with 3P delivery platforms; 4) largely stable unit economics, eventually improving over time, given lower driver incentives, rising frequency, and reduced insurance costs; and 5) achievable 3-year Bookings and EBITDA targets (from 2024 Investor Day) which could prove conservative as recent growth is outpacing guidance parameters.

We also like Instacart (recently upgraded to Outperform) with its 1) best-in-class grocery delivery platform (largest basket size among all three), 2) solid enterprise eCommerce platform, 3) nicely scaling (over $1 billion in annualized revenue) advertising business, 4) attractive buyback program (upsized to $1.65 billion total capacity as of 3Q25), and 5) attractive risk-reward ratio. DoorDash is also well-positioned into 2026 , with continuing investment in initiatives (new products, global tech stack and AI) that support long-term growth. Continuing DashPass adoption and strong execution in its core U.S. restaurants category are supporting accelerating order frequency which is driving order volume acceleration. In addition, new verticals continue to grow, driven by new partnerships in retail and grocery. Its recently launched DashMart Fulfillment should drive higher GOV and new vertical growth, given access to more inventory.

Mobility is bigger than rideshare. It targets personal car ownership and represents globally a $5+ trillion opportunity. We show below the AV/rideshare TAM which is a combination of passenger vehicle and public transport trips in 170+ countries. In the U.S., households spend more on transportation than on any other expenditure ex-housing, with consumers spending ~$1.6 trillion ($13,000 per household). Further, when we analyze rideshare gross bookings at the largest players today (Uber, Lyft, DiDi, and Grab) penetration remains at just over 1%. As such, the introduction of AVs on rideshare platforms is just another ingredient to shifting user behavior from car ownership to rideshare. As highlighted earlier, the macro picture heading into 2026 is a bit blurry, but interestingly, travel is one of the few discretionary verticals still seeing resilient demand. We believe this resilience is supported by the intersection of two factors - the ongoing shift in consumer preferences towards experiences and the bifurcation of consumption patterns. The shift in consumer behavior (consumers increasingly prioritizing experiences and live events over material possessions in their spending) is particularly strong among millennials and Gen Z, which makes it a more durable trend. While a softening economy might slow down that momentum a bit, we don't expect a stall or reversal in 2026. At the same time, the tailwind from resilient consumer spending has endured through the whole of 2025, and we don't expect a reversal in 2026, unless the stock market turns around and ruins the "wealth effect" underpinning this elevated consumption.

· Thematically, AI advances should continue to provide a tailwind to travel demand in 2026, with agentic AI revolutionizing travel commerce by compressing discovery, planning, booking, and servicing into a single conversational journey. · Tactically, several major sporting events are happening in 2026 - including the 2026 Winter Olympics/Paralympics and the 2026 FIFA World Cup - and we expect to see incremental impetus to travel, despite elevated macro uncertainty. While we maintain our Market-Weight stance on global travel for 2026, given the increasing macro pressures on the average consumer, we are somewhat cautious on the travel space as the likelihood of an inflection in demand remains elevated for next year.

When looking at the progress that major online travel platforms have made with AI, we see that overall, Booking and Expedia lead in AI maturity with broad, production-scale deployment across consumer and partner surfaces with measurable adoption. At the same time, Airbnb and Tripadvisor are executing AInative transitions anchored in conversational UX, identity/trust, and proprietary content. AI-first discovery is reshaping traffic patterns with Expedia reporting higher-converting Gen AI traffic and Tripadvisor seeing exponentially growing GEO traffic, though from small bases.

· Booking's Connected Trip strategy shows measurable traction with low double-digit transaction share and mid-20% year-over-year growth in 3Q25, while its partner tools achieved a 73% uplift in satisfaction; · Expedia deploys the broadest AI ecosystem, with over 350 AI models across its marketplace and virtual agents handling nearly half of customer service inquiries while improving NPS and lowering costs; · Airbnb's AI support agent demonstrates early success by reducing human contact by approximately 15% in the U.S., with plans to expand to over 50 languages as part of the company's AI-native concierge vision; · Tripadvisor leverages proprietary content for AI differentiation with AI review summaries achieving ~75% satisfaction across over 30,000 hotels and trip-planner users showing 15x higher ARPU than platform average.

Consumer-facing AI is reshaping discovery, decisioning, and service across the online travel names. AI is also being applied across supply and partnerships to reduce onboarding friction, improve listing quality, automate guest-operator communication, and strengthen trust and compliance. The approaches vary by company, from agentic messaging for accommodation partners to B2B trip planning APIs and governance-first review integrity. AI-first discovery is shifting traveler behavior from list-based search to conversational 'answer engines.' Traffic is increasingly influenced by generative engine optimization (GEO/AEO) and deep integrations with platforms such as Google, OpenAI, and Perplexity. At the same time, AI is transforming ad targeting and content creation, with measurable impacts on direct traffic, loyalty, and cross-vertical attach.

· Introduced an AI customer support assistant with a custom, rich UI inside messaging that enables tailored answers and common actions (e.g., cancel/change) within chat; early U.S. deployment reduced human-agent contact by ~15%, with plans to expand to over 50 languages in 2026. The company positions this as the foundation for an AI-native concierge that integrates conversational search and AI customer service with identity, payments, and messaging across the entire trip lifecycle. · Continued personalization in the core app (e.g., recommended destinations, suggested filters, personalized listing highlights) supports a more tailored discovery experience. · Plans to roll out conversational, multi-turn AI search that outputs natural language and adapts responses to user context; iterative roll-outs targeted through 2026.

· Advancing computer vision-led listing automation: photos can auto-tag amenities, generate listing and neighborhood descriptions, and adapt visuals seasonally, streamlining host onboarding and content quality while enabling better pricing and revenue management. The company positions identity and payments as core rails, citing ~200M verified identities.

· Booking.com is adding natural language search with inspiration (destination highlights) and progressing toward agentic capabilities within its Connected Trip vision. · Launched AI Voice Support (English/German live; Italian/Spanish in testing) for voice-powered trip management, and AI-powered Flight Search Summaries (English-first; broader roll-out planned for 2026) that surface trade-offs like stops vs. price/time. · AI-first integrations with OpenAI and scale benefits from a single global tech stack and rich data enable faster user-side personalization and service automation. · KAYAK AI Mode brings natural-language search directly to the homepage (English, US; more languages/markets coming), blending KAYAK data with ChatGPT to produce contextual results, with voice entry to follow. · Booking reports reduced live agent contact rates and better resolution times via voice-enabled Gen AI in customer service; Priceline's 'Penny' AI assistant added voice and drove higher engagement/conversion.

· Partner-side Smart Messenger/Auto-Reply show strong satisfaction uplift (+73%) - a signal of maturing agentic tooling that is informing consumer experiences. Auto-Reply is live globally and Smart Messenger is rolling out in English-speaking markets including the U.S., U.K., New Zealand, and Australia. · Developing an AI Partner Assistant for onboarding and uses AI to share booking-pattern insights with properties. Agoda complements this with an AI Property AMA Bot answering over 30,000 hotel questions per day and a Content Enhancement Tool that upscales, de-duplicates, re-tags, and ranks over 450 million images, increasing gallery engagement and room-detail checks. · Booking.com's B2B reach expanded via a new Spotnana integration to its latest APIs, enabling access to full inventory and rates, configurable content controls for travel management companies, and improved servicing across languages and payment options.

· Embedded AI in shopping and post-booking flows, including AI filters, property Q&A, and review summaries; improved recommendation models contributed to record attach rates for Brand Expedia. Design flow updates in lodging and post-booking also drove double-digit vacation rental growth. · Insurance personalization delivered the highest attach rates ever; customer service virtual agents now handle nearly half of inquiries while improving NPS and lowering costs. · Actively optimizing for answer engine ecosystems and agentic search, noting Gen AI traffic converts at higher rates than other channels; partnerships include Google, OpenAI, and Perplexity. · Introduced Smart Trip AI, a conversational planner B2B partners can embed for curated, realtime recommendations; also Typeahead API with a 20% search-to-book conversion uplift, and a Lodging Sponsored Listings API to help partners monetize traffic. The company notes over 350 AI models integrated across its marketplace.

· Scale and adoption are reflected in $9.4 billion B2B gross bookings (+26% YoY), with Rapid API the fastest-growing product and the travel-agent business up 25%. Advertising tools also use AI to improve targeting and measurement via its partner ad portal, supporting supply visibility and merchandising without adding operational burden for partners.

· Deployed AI review summaries across hotels, and expanded across restaurants and attractions, with early hotel deployments posting ~75% satisfaction across over 30,000 hotels. · Rolled out an AI travel assistant and conversational trip planning that integrate proprietary content and clickstream data; engagement is rising and ARPU of trip-planner users is ~15x platform average (early scale, growing base). · Advancing integrations (e.g., Amazon Alexa, Microsoft Azure) to extend AI reach and support voice-oriented guidance experiences; directly integrating the Tripadvisor and TheFork brands into ChatGPT. The company has also signed licensing deals with majority of the leading AI companies. · Deploys Gen AI to streamline operator onboarding and improve listing quality, while AI-based content moderation and fraud detection protect marketplace integrity. Its Transparency Report outlines multi-layer moderation and removal of 2.7 million fraudulent reviews and 214,000 AIgenerated reviews.

We believe Booking.com has a sustainable advantage in cross-border travel given its strong position in Europe and APAC (with Agoda). We find the company placed well for continued growth momentum as demand remains strongest in the latter region. Together, Booking.com and Agoda rank in the top five across all travel apps in key countries, including Japan, Thailand, Australia, South Korea, Indonesia, and Malaysia. At the same time, Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky highlighted in November 2024 that the company is focused on the big four countries in Asia: India, China, South Korea, and Japan . While Airbnb does have attractive brand recognition in the region, Booking.com will continue to invest in marketing and supply initiatives, which will sustain a challenging competitive dynamic in 2026E and likely into 2027E.

In 2025, short-term rental (STR) platforms faced heightened compliance costs as compliance complexity increased with cities tightening rules, forcing platforms to verify licenses, and safety standards hardening, requiring centralized compliance ops functions for license/registry validation. U.S. municipalities intensified enforcement with tighter licensing rigor, stay caps, and complaint-response expectations, while platforms increased take-down exposure for listings without valid registration, creating operational complexity for multi-city operators. European regulatory momentum accelerated beyond data sharing with legislators signaling harmonized tools to curb housing pressures while preparing VAT obligations for platforms under ViDA (VAT in the Digital Age), an initiative by the European Commission aimed at modernizing and digitalizing the Value Added Tax system. The EU Parliament called for stronger harmonized measures in 2025, urging night caps, authorization/ permit schemes, zoning restrictions, and potential bans in shortage areas alongside ex ante compliance responsibility for platforms.

The UK introduced comprehensive national oversight with a proposed national register for STRs with expected submissions covering safety compliance and annual occupancy data, targeting an April 2026 launch. Tax obligations expand significantly, with the ViDA regulations making platforms deemed suppliers for VAT from July 1, 2028 and UK councils applying up to 100% Council Tax premium on second homes from April 2025. Still, alternative accommodations was the second-fastest growing segment after attractions in 2025. Booking reported roughly 10% year-over-year growth in both listings (reaching 8.6 million) and room nights in 3Q25. Similarly, Airbnb reported both listings and room nights (and seats) growing at roughly 9% year-over-year. We expect alternative accommodations to continue outpacing hotels in 2026.

In online travel, we continue to favor Booking Holdings because: 1) we believe the company currently has best-in-class AI capabilities with broad, production-scale deployment showing measurable adoption and positive P&L impact; 2) we like Booking's scale and more diversified market and product footprint; 3) we like the level of progress with Connected Trip and alternative accommodations; 4) new verticals (flights and attractions) continue to drive strong growth; and 5) its loyalty program is driving higher booking frequency and direct traffic to the platform. We remain on the sidelines for Airbnb , although we like the level of product innovation and platform improvements (which enhance the user experience and drive growth), as well as their expansion internationally and into new categories (experiences, services, hotels). However, both international markets and new categories are in their early innings and would take some time to become meaningful contributors, particularly given that Airbnb faces strong competition across both from Booking, Expedia, and Tripadvisor. Regulatory risks remain another key overhang to the longer-term model of Airbnb.

While we remain neutral on Expedia , we want to highlight that we like their cost discipline (driving margin expansion) and management focus on strategic priorities including delivering more value to travelers, growth investments (AI, new product features, etc.), and operational efficiencies. But with macro uncertainty still elevated and given Expedia's higher exposure to the US market (facing stronger headwinds than international markets), we are watching closely for signs of softening travel demand. We also remain on the sidelines for Tripadvisor ; we are encouraged by management decision to shift operating model to focus on Experiences and AI but highlight elevated execution risk (always present in Tripadvisor's history). We appreciate the company's cost savings program (20% headcount reduction) expected to generate $85 million in annual savings by 2027, but Tripadvisor's core challenge remains translating its industry-leading traffic and strong planning influence into bookings.
